JULIUS MENDELL (through an interpreter.) I saw the two prisoners—gave a sovereign—I do not remember whether I laid it on the table—the two prisoners were present—I gave it for them, in consequence of what Mr. Roen
baun✗ told me—I expected to be taken to New York—I went down and saw✗ the ship—we walked through the Thames Tunnel to it—it was in some cand✗—I do not know the name of the dock—the two prisoners were with me—they showed me about the ship.

M'Lean. Q. Did you go with me on the Tuesday? A. I cannot tell the day—some others went with me—you introduced me to Captain Gardner who was with the carpenter, between decks, making the berths for passengers, as you said—I appointed to meet Captain Gardner, at three o'clock in the afternoon, to make arrangements.

ISAAC SAMUEL ROSENBAUM
re-examined. I saw every one of the nine✗ persons pay their 1l. each—M'Lean took some, and Gardner took some.
EMANUEL MORITZ . I paid 1l. to go out with the Recovery—I paid a 10✗ guilder-piece and some shillings.
M'Lean. I acknowledge I saw the whole money paid, and put in the box.

NICHOLAS GIBSON . I live in Lower John-street, Commercial-road. I am✗ owner of the Recovery—she is lying in the Surrey-canal—you get to it by going through the Thames-tunnel—M'Lean called on me on the 26th of April—I had never seen him before—he made some offer about chartering the vessel—Gardner was not captain of the vessel, my brother was—I told him I would not allow the ship to go out without my brother being captain—if M'Lean stated that Gardner was captain of that vessel he stated what was wrong—I never heard of Gardner going on board my vessel and showing it, till I was at the police-court—there was nothing at all going on to prepares✗ the vessel for emigrants.

M'Lean. Q. From what passed between us, would you not suppose that I should be able to negotiate with you? A. You offered me a very excellent price—I told you if I found the partied respectable I might charter the ship—I received a note from you—this is it—(read—"No. 2, Sidney-street—Sir, according to promise I take the liberty of addressing you on the subject

of chartering the barque Recovery;—when I saw you I offered 8s. per ton per month; I have this morning seen your brother, and offered him 10s. per ton; and considering the age of the vessel, there is no doubt you will con
sider the offer sufficient; the vessel to be chartered for four months certain, at 10s. a ton per month; the chartered pay the port charges, provision, and sea
men's wages. Another vessel being offered, your early answer will oblige. Yours, &c."

M'Lean. Q. Did I not say if your brother took charge of her, it would be no objection? A. Yes—you would do anything to get the ship—my brother told me you had seen him, and arranged at 10 guineas a month—I told you I would not accept it till I had inquired as to the respectability of the party—you said you were only an agent in the matter—I do not know that you had a right to tell Gardner that you were likely to come to an agreement.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Ten shillings a ton would have been a famous freightage? A. Yes—I could not let my vessel for one-third of that.

M'Lean. Q. Did you not say you were getting 90l. a month in the coal trade? A. Yes—I said I would consider it, and give you an answer in writing—you called on Thursday morning and told me Captain Gardner was in custody.
DAVID JOHNSON . I know the prisoner M'Lean—he is a journeyman baker and was in my employ up to Nov. last.

M'Lean. It was only for the time I was in your employ that you knew me in that capacity. Witness. No—may acquaintance with you took place last July—you represented that you knew me twenty years ago, but, to the best of my knowledge, I never saw you before.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Was he a good hand at journeyman baking? A. Yes, a very good one, the best in England, I think.

M'Lean Defence. I have endeavoured, as far as lay in my power, to carry out the views and do justice to every person that employed me; I admit these people paid their money; I saw it paid; it was done with the best intention; I made an arrangement with Gardner, to take sixty passengers out—about the 6th of May, I had met Captain Gardner, named to him the sub
ject; he told me of the Recovery; he took me down to look at it, and wished me to wait on the owner; I waited on Mr. Gibson, and you have heard what he has said—with respect to Rosenbaum I was employed by him to do the best I possibly could to dispatch these emigrants, and I was to receive one-half of the profits—with respect to anything else, I leave it entirely in your own hands; I have got my conscience clear, and here I stand innocent of any
thing wrong—there never was fraud intended by Captain Gardner or me.

Gardner's Defence. I called on M'Lean on Saturday evening, the 24th of April; he mentioned having a number of passengers, and I thought it would suit my purpose; I called on a corn merchant in the City, and asked if he would join a charter party to transport these emigrants; he said it was a de
viation from his business, but if it would further my views he had no object
tion; I turned my attention to a vessel called the Recovery; I commissioned Mr. M'Lean to call on the owner, and from what he said I was of opinion she could be chartered; on the Monday I was at Mr. Ireland's, Rosenbaum came in, and I named having a vessel about to proceed to New York; Rosenbaum asked, "What will you take these passengers for?" I named 5l.; he said, "What commission will you allow me?" I think I said 4s.; he said he was in the habit of having 6s. from Phillips and Tiplady, if I would give him the same he would give me the preference; I agreed to it, and he seemed anxious✗

that they should see the vessel; I, knowing they wanted to get away, called on a friend, a shipwright, and asked him to walk on board and give me as estimate of what it would come to, to fit it up, in case the charter-party came to a close; they left me about eleven o'clock on Tuesday morning, and agreed to meet me at Mr. Ireland's at three o'clock; I met them, and instead of paying the 5l. it was agreed that 1l. should be paid then, and the remainder when they were on board; it made no difference to me, knowing I had a re
sponsible party to join me in the charter; they paid 9s.; the money was put into the box, and after stopping a short time, Mr. Rosenbaum and his daughter asked me to leave an agreement with them, as they might get more passen
gers; I did so, and the next morning I made an arrangement to proceed to Mr. Ireland's; I went to his house about one o'clock on the Wednesday; I left a message that I was on business in the corn-market, and should be back at three o'clock; I returned, and saw Mr. M'lean; I left him full power in negotiate anything that might occur; I called at Mr. Ireland's again in the evening; I was taken into custody; I have not had opportunity to get a solicitor; under these circumstances I applied to traverse my trail, and had his Lordship granted my request I should have had not only a solicitor but a Counsel; I have been a master and owner of a ship the last three years; I commanded a ship for Mr. Soames in 1844.

M'LEAN—
GUILTY .

GARDNER—
GUILTY .

hi.rs: Transported for Seven Years

div1.p: (There was another indictment against the prisoners.)

1273.
CHARLES MADELL was indicted for
stealing 1 dressing-case value 15s.; 1 pair of scissors, 1s.; 2 razors, 3s.; 2 brushes, 4s.; 1 razors strop, 1s.; 1 comb, 6d.; 1 looking-glass, 2s.; 1 knife, 6d.; 2 bone rollers 4s.; 1 pair of tweezers, 6d.; 1 nail-file, 1s.; and 1 bottle, 2s. 6d.; the goods of
Samuel Ellett: and
HENRY EDWARDS
, for that he feloniously did incite, move, procure, counsel, hire, and command the said
Charles Madell the same felony to do an commit.

SAMUEL ELLETT. I am a dressing-case maker, and live in Queen-street, City-road. On the 17th of April the prisoner Madell came to my house—he said he was a dressing-case maker, that he had a customer from Chelmsford, and he wanted some good dressing-cases—he said he wanted better goods than he had got—I sent my son with him with three cases—my son and Madell came back—he ordered five cases, three of one sort and two of the other, and asked if I had got some envelope-boxes—I said, "Yes"—he selected some, and four dressing-cases, and my son went him to show them—he returned with an order for once of the dressing-cases, which was to be sent to a public-house in Old-street—I told my son not to leave anything without the money, on way account—my son brought back the bag with the samples, and when I looked into it, there was once dressing-case short—I got the rest of the order ready, and at nine o'clock in the evening I went with my son to Baltion✗ street—I found Madell had left, and Edwards was about to leave—my son went into the house—he came out again, and said I was to go home directly, for Madell had gone to my house—we hurried home, and he had not been then—I said, "We must go and look after these men"—we went, and in going along, we saw the prisoner Edwards—my son said, "That is the gentleman that represent himself as Mr. Whiffin, from Chelmsford"—I stopped him,

and said, "Are you Mr. Whiffin, from Chelmsford?"—he said, "No. I am a Londoner bred and born"—I said, "Where there?"—he then said, "I came from Wales"—I said, "You have been looking at some dressing-cases"—he said, "I have"—I took him to my house, and he pointed out the very dressing-cases that they had been looking at—this is the card that Madell left me, and he wrote on the back of it the name of Whiffin.

Madell. Q. I represented myself as a fancy cabinet-maker; I believe you know that is true? A. No.—you were a perfect stranger to me—you said you had done business for respectable people—you named a person in St. Paul's—churchyard—I inquired there, and they do not know you—you mentioned the name of Whiffin—I asked you what trade he was, and what you dealt in—the second time you came you showed me a printed paper—you said Mr. Whiffin paid ready money—I considered I was dealing with Mr. Whiffin.

FREDERICK CLEMENT ELLETT . I am the son of Samuel Ellett. On Saturday evening, the 17th of April, I saw Madell at my father's house—I took some dressing-cases to Madell's house—he went there and said, "My customer, Mr. Whiffin, is at the public-house over the way—we will and see him"—we went to the Sir John Falstaff, in Old-street, and there I saw Edwards, and Madell there gave me a glass of ale—I do not think they had spoken together before he gave it, but they were standing close to each other at the table—the ale made me feel a sort of dizziness in my head—I never drank any other ale that had the same effect on me—when I had had the ale, they began to look at the dressing-cases, and I heard Edwards say, "Will you take 3l.?"—Madell said, "No"—they offered me some more ale, and they went our together—Madell returned by himself in two or these minutes, and said he would have five dressing-cases—he gave me this paper, and he said he would go back to my father, to know how soon they could be got ready—he went with me—he talked about Chelmsford—he said Mr. Whiffin was brother to Miss Whiffin, and that she was the principal person in the busi
ness—he said what a nice place Chelmsford was, and that Mr. Whiffin had his own horse and cart, and he wanted to drive down that night—I understood that he meant Mr. Edwards, the person I had seen—I had not heard him address Edwards by any name—when we got to my father's, the goods were looked out, and an order given to take some dressing-cases to Baltic-street—I took four dressing-cases and two envelope-boxes—when I got to Madell's house, he said, "My customer is here now, I will take them up stairs, and show them to him"—he took the bag up stairs, and brought it down in a few minutes—he gave me the bag, and said, "Bring the other dressing-cases at nine o'clock, to the public-house in Old-street"—I went home, and found one case was missing—I went at nine o'clock—Madell was gone—I saw Edwards standing at the bar—he said Madell was gone to our house—we went there, but could not find him.

Madell. Q. What time in the afternoon was it that I first had the dress
ing-cases? A. I cannot say—I should think between four and five o'clock—you did not say that Mr. Edward's name was Whiffin, but you talked of Mr. Whiffin in going along—you gave me a glass of ale—you drank out of another glass, not the same that I had—I went down stairs when I went into your house—you did not say you had got a case, and you would pay my father for that one with the others—I thought that one was in the bag, or I should not have left it—my father ordered me not—I brought the others, which were ordered, a little after nine—it was not more than a

quarter after nine—you did not tell me to bring a bill and receipt with them—I asked you if I should bring one—you said, "No"—you did not say, "Bring a bill for them and the one I have got"—you did not say a word about keeping one—I went back, and missed one—it is about ten minutes' walk from my father's house to yours—you did not say you was going to take the dressing-case out to show.

DAVID ABRAHAMS . I was at that time a City police-constable, No. 150. I took Edwards into custody at No. 8, Jewin-street—in going to the station, he said his name was Mr. Whiffin, and that he was an agent, at Chelmsford—I asked him if he knew a person named Madell—he said he had been in company with a friend who had made a dupe of him—when he got to the sta
tion he said his name was Edwards—I said, "You told me your name was Whiffin"—he said he had not.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How comes it you are not in the police now? A. I resigned—I was ordered to resign—I had been in the police before—Edwards and I were alone when he told me his name was Mr. Whiffin.

JOHN HARVEY . (police-constable G 118.) I took Madell into custody—he said he did not steal the case, he had it in the regular way of business—he did not say whom he wanted to show it to—he said if I went to the George and Blue Boar in Holborn I should find a person of the name of Cook, who would give me the case—I went there, and could not find Cook—I found on✗ Madell, at the station, a letter, purporting to come from Charles Cook—this is it—(read—"To Mr. Madell,—Sir, I could not get in my rents from Colchester, or I would have sent you the account—I will be sure to sead✗ 17l. some day next week; you can make me twelve desks,—CHARLES Cook.")—Madell also showed me a printed bill of Miss Whiffin's, and said this would satisfy me—I also found on him some bills drawn by Charles Madell, and accepted by Henry Edwards.
Madell. Q. On Sunday morning you took me, and searched my place? A. Yes—I found the dressing-case at your own house.

CHARLES GOODMAN . I know the prisoner Madell—there was a time when he was a partner of mine—it commenced last July, and ended in Dec. last—I know his handwriting—this letter, purporting to come from Mr. Cook, is Madell's writing—I am a commission-agent—when I was in partnership with Madell I was a fancy cabinet-maker.
MARY ANN WHIFFIN . I reside at Chelmsford with my sister. I do not know Madell—he had nothing to do with my business—this is one of my shop bills.
Madell. I called on you at Chelmsford. Witness. I never saw you before.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Have you a brother at Chelmsford? A. Yes, a house-agent and appraiser.

SAMUEL ELLETT
re-examined. This is my dressing-case.

Madell's Defence. The dressing-case I am charged with stealing, is the one that the prosecutor wished me to show; I never named the name of Whiffin as a customer, but merely showed the circular to describe the sort of goods I sold—while I was I the prosecutor's shop, I stated that I had been through Chelmsford, Colchester, and Essex; I gave my right address; he knew nothing about Whiffin; on the day stated, Edwards and I dined at the Sir John Falstaff; I expected to meet the party the cases were for; he was in my debt, and I was to draw a bill on him; the landlord got me the stamp✗ and I did; I went to the Sir John Falstaff about nine o'clock; the witness

did not come; I left word with Edwards that I was gone out about money, and would call on him that night or early on Monday morning; the party I called on for money had nothing but a check for 20l.; I had left this case behinds me on the road; this was all the same evening; I was at home by half-past ten, and next morning two policemen came and said I was in cus
tody for a dressing-case; I said it was a fair sale, I had purchased the goods, and I should pay on Monday morning; I told the prosecutor if he would come with me I would take him to the person who would pay the money; I had not the slightest intention to cheat him—up to the last four months I had fourteen men at work on my premises; I had an execution in my pre
mises, and 160l. of stock was sold to pay 60l.—the reason I did not give the prosecutor the name of my customer was, that I expected to see that person at the Sir John Falstaff; had the prosecutor waited till Monday, all would have been settled; Edwards never heard the name of Whiffin.

MADELL—
GUILTY . Aged 33.—
Transported for Seven Years.
[see the next case.]

EDWARDS—
NOT GUILTY .

1274.
CHARLES MADELL . and
HENRY EDWARDS were again indicted for
conspiracy.

LEWIS COLLINS . I in Green's-terrace, Clerkenwell—I am a goldsmith—I manage the business of my father, Francis Collins—I have known Ed
wards many years as a watch-gilder and colourer. On the 10th of April he came to my shop, between six and seven o'clock in the evening—he asked if I had any gentlemen's short guards to show to a gentleman that he thought he could sell them to—I showed him some—he selected two, and said he would take them to show the gentleman—he came again, and said the gen
tleman had kept one, and he returned the other—he came again, and said the gentleman would prefer the one he returned to the one he kept—I let him have the other—he came again, and said the gentleman would keep the two at the price I had named—they were worth 4l. 15s.—I have seen them since at the pawnbroker's—when I saw Edwards at the station I asked him how he came to serve me so—he said he had not been able to see the gentle
man.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. You have known Edwards many years? A. Yes—I do not know that he was once in a very large way of business—I have known him ever since I can remember, doing little odd jobs—he was engaged in the watch gilding trade—when he came to me on that Saturday evening, he asked if I had any gentleman's short guards—he se
lected two of different patterns—he said he would show them to the gentle
man and if the gentleman chose one he would bring me the other back, and bring the money for the one he kept.

JAMES SWAINE . I am shopman to Mr. Reeves, a pawnbroker, in Red
cross-street—Madell pawned these two chains with me, in the name of John Cook, one on the 12th of April, for 1l. 5s., and the other on the 14th of April for 1l. 1s.—he came again on the 16th of April, and I advanced him 4s. more.

RICHARD JOHN COVENTRY . I am a gold curb chain-maker, in Parceval-street Clerkenwell. About the 6th of March Edwards came to my shop—I had known him before—he brought Madell with him, and said he was a highly respectable tradesman in the habit of selling watches and chains, and he required some chains to show to a gentleman he was about selling a watch to—he said I might trust him—they selected three chains—Madell said he wanted them to show to a gentleman he was about selling a watch to—I said,

if one was sold I should expert cash—Madell said, "Certainly," and if not sold they were to be returned—they went away—I heard nothing more about them for three or four days—I then went to Edward's place of business—he was not there—I then met him, and he said he would go to Madell's and see about him—I expressed myself surprised at their not being returned—I after
wards saw Madell at No. 2, Wellington-street—I went to took after my chairs—I told him I insisted on having them back directly—he said he would go to the gentleman, who was a customer, at Knightsbridge, and get them that evening—I afterwards met Edwards, and I said it was not a debt, and I should take proceedings—shortly Madell called, and left two of the chairs—I have not got the other chain, nor do I know where it is—I spoke to Edwards about that—I asked him if he knew what sort of a character Madell was, and if he had heard of some proceeding going on—he said yes, and he was much astonished, for had know him some time, and thought him a respect
able man, and that he should have nothing more to do with him.

Cross-examined. Q. Did Edwards afterwards agree to pay you 2s. 6d. a week for the goods? A. Yes, and he left one half-crown—I had known Edwards before for two or three years—he is a watch-colourer and glider—I have an I O U of his, by which he agreed to pay half-a-crown a week for the amount of the chain.
Madell. I returned the two best chains to you. Witness. Yes—the one not returned was worth 3l. 17s.

FREDERICK CLEMENT ELLETT . I am the son of Samuel Ellett—I first saw the prisoners on the 17th of April—Madell came to my father's shop—he wanted some dressing-cases—I went with him to the public-house—he said his customer, Mr. Whiffin, was at the public-house over the way, and I went to see him—Edwards was the only person he showed them to in the public-house—I was introduced to Edwards—I supposed him to be Whiffin—when Madell go in he began to talk to Edwards, and showed him the dressing-cases—they talked together some time, and they went out together—Madell came back and brought this paper—he said, "I want five dressing
cases; I will go to your father and ask what time he can have them ready"—we made up this order—I went at nine o'clock, and when I got there Madell was not there—Edwards was there alone—I said, "Is Mr. Madell here?"—he said, "No, he is gone down to your house; he left word that you were to go back directly—you will find him at your house"—I went back, and he had not been—I then went out with my father, and met Edwards is✗ Aldersgate-street—Madell said Mr. Whiffin was brother to Miss Whiffin, and that she was principal in the business.
DAVID ABRAHAM . I took Edwards—he said his name was Mr. Whiffin, and he was an agent at Chelmsford.
JOHN HARVEY (police-constable G 118.) I found these two bills and this letter in Madell's pocket-book.
CHARLES GOODMAN . This letter is Madell's writing, and these two bills likewise.

RHODES MOULD . I am clerk at Clerkenwell Police-court—when Mr. Ellett was making his statement, Madell interrupted, and said, "I don't Know Mr. Whiffin; there was no Mr. Whiffin mentioned;" and then he said, "I served my time to Edwards"—Edwards said, "When he met me he asked if my name was Whiffin—the name was strange to me—he asked me if I had seen some boxes—I said, "Yes, and very pretty they were."

RICHARD JOHN COVENTRY
re-examined. Q. When was it you got the I O U? A. I do not remember—it was some time after this transactions took place.

Madell. I am no way connected with the chains; I know nothing about them; I had three of Mr. Coventry to show to a gentleman, one of them at 3l. 17s. was kept; I said I would pay for it in a few weeks; the others I returned; since then I find Mr. Edwards has agreed to pay it himself; there was 2l. 15s. due to me from Mr. Edwards.

COURT to RICHARD JOHN COVENTRY. Q. When was it you had the con
versation with Edwards about the character of Madell? A. Within a fort
night of the 6th of March—it was certainly less than a fortnight when I had the I O U.

MADELL—
GUILTY . Aged 33.—[See page 177.]

EDWARDS—
GUILTY . Aged 47.—
Confined Six Months.

div0.p: PRESENT—Mr. Alderman MUSGROVE, and EDWARD BULLOCK, Esq.

p.hi: Fourth July, before Edward Bullock, Esq.

div1.p:
1275.
RICHARD HARRISON was indicted
for unlawfully assaulting
Elizabeth Turner.

GUILTY .—
Confined Two Months.

1276.
GEORGE CARTER was indicted
for a common assault.
(The Prisoner received a good character.)

hi.rs: GUILTY. Aged 32.—Recommended to mercy by Jury.—

div1.p:
1277.
GEORGE BALL was indicted
for unlawfully carnally knowing and abusing Mary Ann Gradwell, aged 10 years and 11 months; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 50.—
Confined Twelve Months.

1278.
WILLIAM LEONARD was indicted
for a common assault.

ELIZABETH LEOANARD . My daughter, Elizabeth, lives with me—the pri
soner is my son—he did not live with me, he used to come sometimes to see me—he came on Sunday, the 11th April—he used always to behave very kindly to me when he was sober, but when he is drunk he is very outrageous at times—he does not often get drunk—he was sober when he came, but went out, and at a quarter to six came back drunk—I and my daughter were there drinking tea—I got up to let him sit down—he said I did not act as a mother to get up to let her child sit down, that I ought to let him get a chair himself—he asked me if I would take anything to drink, and said he would fetch me something—I said I had much better not, but if he would give me a pint of beer for my supper I would much rather—he seemed very angry at that, and upset my table with the tea-things on it—I took up the poker, and said if he did not go out of my place I would make him—I did that because, if he sees me frightened when he is tipsy, it makes him think worse of it—I did not do anything with the poker, but said I would use it if he did not leave the room—I saw a knife in his hand during the transaction—I do not think that was before I caught hold of the poker, but I was so agitated at the time that I do not Know; but when I saw it, I laid hold of his arm, and told him to drop the knife—I cut my thumb and finger very slightly—they bled, but not

very much—it bled by the heat and the passion I was in—I did not put anything to it—I think he took the knife before I took the poker—after the cut with the knife I took the poker, and he laid hold of my arms behind me—I did not use it, he prevented me—he had hold of me, and I had no power of doing anything—I hit him with my head and made his mouth and nose bleed, and then he gave me some blows on my head, and about my ear—I do not know whether I fell or whether he knocked me down—I was very ill with influenza at the time—my girl called a policeman, and I was taken to the hos
pital, and was there a fortnight.

ELIZABETH LEONARD . I am the prosecutrix's daughter, and sister to the prisoner. I remember the prisoner coming in drunk on Sunday evening, at a quarter past six o'clock—I was taking tea with my mother—she asked him to sit down—he did not sit down—he said, "If you were like a mother you would let me get a chair myself"—he asked if she would have anything to drink—she said she would rather have a pint of beer for her supper—he got very angry, and said, "How would you look if I were to upset the table?"—she said, "Don't do that, have a cup of tea"—he upset the table—there was a knife laying there—he had it in his band—he went towards the fire-place with it, where my mother was—he went towards her—he did not do anything, he only went towards her—my mother got it out of his hand—this is my mark to my deposition—it was read over to me—(read—"The prisoner took up the knife, went towards her, and made an attempt to stab her with the knife in the chest")—I did say that my mother saved herself and got a cut—the prisoner left the room, and returned, my mother took up the poker, and said if he did not go she would use it—he caught hold of her hand, and she did not use it—he struck her, and she struck him with her head and made his nose bleed—he knocked her down.

EDWARD VOKIN (policeman.) On the 11th of April I was called to the house, and found Mr. Leonard standing, leaning near the banisters, bleed
ing from the nose and mouth, and the prisoner standing alongside of her, bleeding too—I asked her who had been beating her; she said her son—I asked him what made him do it, he said, it was a family affair,—he was drunk.
Prisoner. I stated to you that I had been struck in the face. Witness. Not a word about it.

BEMERSIDE HAYWARD . I am house-surgeon at St. Bartholomew's Hos
pital. On the 11th of April Mr. Leonard was brought there—I examined her—she appeared very much injured—there was a swelling on the side of her head, on her wrist, and the whole side of her body—it appeared to be from repeated blows—there had also been blows on the back of the head—I considered her in danger for a short time—she had inflammation in the side, being in a precarious state of health.

Prisoner's Defence. I have been with my mother nine or ten years, and did all for her that laid in my power; I sat down to breakfast with her on Sunday morning, afterwards went out and met a friend, and remained with him till about half-past five o'clock; I went home, a few words ensued; I was struck in the face, and having had a little drop of drink, I was provoked to do it; if I had not had the drink I should have had command over my temper; I am sincerely sorry for what has happened, I have been a teetotaler some time.

ELIZABETH LEONARD , Jun., re-examined. He was not in the habit of getting drunk lately—when he was sober he behaved well to his mother—he had not lived with us for two or three weeks—at this time there was only
my mother and myself at home—the prisoner is a printer, and when he was living with us, he used to bring some of his wages to his mother.

hi.rs: GUILTY. Aged 30.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury, having been six weeks in prison—

div0.p: PRESENT.—Sir JOHN PIRIE, Knight; Mr. RECORDER; and Mr. Alderman WOOD.

div1.p:
1279.
JOSEPH CLARKSON and
WILLIAM EDWARD SCHOTT
LANDER were indicted for
a misdemeanor.
NOT GUILTY .

1280.
ROBERT HARRISON was indicted
for unlawfully assaulting
William Stevens, with intent to commit b—y.—2nd COUNT, for an in
decent assault.

hi.rs: GUILTYon the 2nd Count. Aged 48.—

div0.p: PRESENT—Mr. Alderman THOMPSON and Mr. COMMON SERGEANT.

p.hi: First Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
1281.
JOSEPH BRUNSDEN was indicted
for embezzlement.

WILLIAM CREED PILCHER . I keep a chandler's-shop in St. Helen's-place, Clerkenwell—the prisoner was my errand-boy—it was his duty to receive money for me—if he received this 2s. 9 1/2 d., and 2s. 6 3/4 d., he did not pay those sums to me, nor say any thing about them.

Cross-examined by Mr. ROBINSON. Q. When did you give him into custody? A. On the 1st of May—the second of these payments was on the 24th of April—he was in a school, and at his leisure time he attended to me—I did not pay him wages—I used to give him something occasionally—I employed him to get this money, and I had done so before—if any one paid him, he was to bring the money to me—it is about three years and a half ago since I first took him—he has received a great deal of money, at different times—I have a wife; if he had paid this money to her, it would have been right; she was not in the shop on the evening of the 24th of April—I cannot say whether she was there on the 17th of April.
SUSAN HOWELL . On the 17th of April, I paid the prisoner 2s. 9 1/2 d. for his master, and on the 24th of April, 2s. 6 3/4 d.—my bills came receipted, and he gave them to me.
NOT GUILTY .

1282.
JOHN CLARKE was indicted
for stealing 129 sovereigns, and 55 half-sovereigns; the monies of
Sarah Truman.

SARAH TRUMAN . I live in Kepple-street, and keep a beer-shop—I have been living with the prisoner for some years as his wife—before I lived with him, I had about 200l. in my possession—I paid 40l. of it to go into the house which I live in—I had got this money at various times in service, and liv
ing as housekeeper with Mr. Scott—the prisoner did not know I was possessed✗

of this money—on the 6th of May, I went out for the whole day—I returned home about a quarter-past twelve o'clock in the evening—the prisoner was not at home—he came home at past two o'clock—on the afternoon of the next day, I missed his hat-box, and then his coat and all his clothes—I then looked at my box, and found it had been broken open—I missed a green purse, containing money—I asked the prisoner if he had taken away his clothes himself—he said, he had not, but Mr. Parker (who lodged in the house) had taken out a bundle last night, at six o'clock—I gave him in charge, for✗ stealing my purse—I went with him to the police-station—the inspector refused to take the charge—I was desired to go home, and look the place over—I missed another bag, containing money, when I came home—I missed altogether, more than one hundred sovereigns, and some half-sovereigns—I gave the prisoner in charge again—I went on the Saturday to Montpelier-row, and found the whole of my property, 156l. in sovereigns and half-sovereigns

Cross-examined by MR. O'BRAEN. Q. You did not know till you found it, how much had lost? A. I knew by what I had taken from it, what I had left—I have been living with the prisoner between four and five years—I have kept the beer-shop about three years—the prisoner is a labourer
he works at one thing or another—he was employed in a cow-shed when I first knew him—he had 18s. a-week—he did not bring his wages home—what he brought home was very little—it went in support of house—he worked, at times, after the beer-house was taken—after he came from work he might have attended a little to the business—he never paid money, he might take have money—I had lodgers in the house—I sometimes received 7s.✗ or 8s. a-week from them, sometimes less—I could not save any of that—I took some from the money I had saved—I never added any to it for four years—I could not tell to a sovereign or two what I had there—the money was in the purse four years ago—this bag is one that I have had about two years—I look some money from one, and put it into the other—on the Friday, after the charge was dismissed, he held up a bag tome and said, "I have got your money"—he said, "You had a spree last night, I will have one to
night"—I had no means of living except what I took from the lodgers, and the proceeds of the beer-shop—I paid 27l. a-year rent, and the license was 3l. 6s. a-year—the prisoner paid the license—I gave him the money to pay it with—I paid the rent—the receipts were not in my name.

MR. HUDDLESTONE. Q. You say when he came back he held up a bag to you, and said he had got your money? A. Yes; that was after he had been to the inspector and had the charge dismissed—in the morning I had said to him, "Will you have the kindness to clean the pots to-day"—he said, "No; I will never clean another pot as long as I live—my name is Walker "—he said, "I have got plenty of money, I am going to enjoy my
self"—that was before I had missed the money—when I charged him with taking my money, he said he knew nothing at all of it, nor yet of his clothes—he said he did not know I was possessed of a farthing, and when he came back from the inspector he pulled out a small bag in which he carried his own money, and thrust it at me and said, "There is your b——y money, you got it out of b——y old Scott"—I had all this money before I went to live with the prisoner.
COURT. Q. Do you swear positively that you had all these sovereigns before you lived with the prisoner? A. I do; and none of them were got in our joint concern after we were living together.

GEORGE HERBERT . I am a cab man. I was with my cab at the Admiral Keppel stand on the night of Thursday, 6th May—the prisoner came to me From twelve to half-past twelve o'clock at night; he got into the cab, and I drove

him to Montpelier-row, Hammersmith—I took a hat-box and a bundle there—I brought the prisoner back to Collage-street, Chelsea—he asked me what my fare was, I said 4s.—he paid me, and he said, "Here is 6d. more, if you know nothing"—that was 6d. over my fare—I afterwards saw the same bundle opened, and there were 156 sovereigns in it.
Cross-examined. Q. What house did you leave it in? A. In the middle house in Montpelier-row, on the right hand—I did not know the prisoner before.
JOHN MURRAY (police-constable B 223.) I was present at the opening of the bundle—William Henry Edwards lives in the house, in Montpelier-row—he told me he was a basket-marker.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 38.—
Confined Six months.

1283.
ELLEN MUNICAN and
ELLEN SULLIVAN were indicted for
stealing 6 blankets, value 3l.; 8 sheets, 1l. 1 rug, 12s.; and 1 pair of drawers, 6s.; the goods of
William Brown, their master; and that Sullivan had been before convicted of felony.

WILLIAM BROWN . I live in Stratton-terrace, Shadwell. The two pri
soners were in my service—Munican left me on Saturday, the 10th April, and Sullivan left on Monday the 12th—when she had left, I missed the articles stated—I had Munican taken up—she said she took two blankets and pawned them in one shop, and one blanket at another shop, and had shared the money with Sullivan.

MARY ANN SYRELL . I live servant with Mr. Brown. On Saturday, the 10th April, Sullivan took a blanket off the bed—she took it into the back room, folded it up, and gave it to Munican, at the bottom of the stairs—I saw her do it, and Munican directly afterwards took it out.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Where were you? A. up stairs, in the sane room—it was taken before me—it is a lodging-house for sailors—there are not many persons coming in and out.

SAMUEL SMITH . I am a pawnbroker. I have two duplicates of a blanket pawned for half-a-crown, in the name of Ann Brown—the person who pawned it had one duplicate and I had the other—it was pawned on Saturday the 10th of April, and taken out on the Monday—I cannot say it was by either of the prisoners.
EBENEZER CLARK . I am assistant to Mr. Hall, a pawnbroker, in High-street—I have the duplicate of a pair of blankets pawned by a female, but redeemed again.

WILLIAM CHARLES POTTER (police-constable K 212.) I went to Wapping workhouse, to apprehend Munican—I told her I wanted her, I wanted her, for robbing her master of some blankets and sheets—she said, "I am very sorry I did take the blankets and sheets"—I then went to Sullivan, I told her wanted her for taking a sheet and blanket—she said she did not, but she had received 1s. 3d., part of half-a-crown which Munican pawned a blanket for.

HENRY M'KAY (police constable K 54.) I produce a certificate of Sulli
van's former conviction—(read—Convicted the 23rd March, 1847, and confined ten days, solitary)—she is the person.

MUNICAN—
GUILTY. Aged 17.—Recommended to mercy by prosecutor.

SULIVAN—
GUILTY. Aged 16.—Recommended to mercy by prosecutor

1284.
ABRAHAM BERLYN was indicted
for stealing 15 pairs of shoes value 1l. 8s. 9d.; the goods of
Abraham Solomon, his master.

ABRAHAM SOLOMON (through an interpreter.) The prisoner was in my ✗ vice. On the 18th of March he took out fifteen pairs of shoes—he said he sold them to Mr. Jones—he did not give me the money—he made me enter them✗ in the book to Mr. Jones, fifteen pairs of shoes, at 15s. a-dozen, 1l. 3s. 9d.—he had leave to sell shoes.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. How long have you been in Eng
land? A. Eighteen months—I have been in business about twelve months in Goulston-square, Whitechapel—I am a native of France—I know Ments—I went honourably, there and came away honourably—my wife did not come to this country with me—she lived in France till I had lived here about eight months, when I wrote to her to come—I did not leave her there in any business—I gave up business when I left—I know nothing about her being put into prison for concealing my effects—I was oncei n partnership with a man named Altham—I have not been to Mr. Hart, the beadle of the Great Synagogue, and asked him for 9l. to keep away from this prosecution—Mr. Hart has been to my house and inquired what the prisoner had dose, and I told him all the circumstances about it—I can swear I did not ask for 9l. to keep away from this prosecution—I did not go to the Rev. Dr. Alder and ask him for money—he sent his servant for me; I went, and heard what he wanted of me—the prisoner told me he had been a wholesale shoe
maker on his own account—I did not agree with him that he was to bring me his connexion—he was to find a connexion—we were not to divide the profits—he had 25s. a-week—I have his receipts for that—he was not to receive 1l. a-week and one quarter of the profits—he was not to have any✗ portion of the profits—he has complained to me about the way in which I keep my books.
JAMES JONES . I sometimes purchase things of the prisoner—I did not purchase any shoes of him on the 18th of March.
Cross-examined. Q. You have purchased things of the prisoner? A. Yes Abel Solomon was known to me, through the prisoner—the prisoner was the person I dealt with, and I paid him on delivery.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

hi.rs: GUILTY.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor—

div1.p:
1285.
GEORGE FRENCH was indicted
for stealing 7lbs. of potatoes value 6d., the goods of
Charles Burrell, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Two Months.

1286.
AGNES FITZGERLAND was indicted
for stealing 1 seedling plant called a camellia-plant, value 2l.; 2 plants, called chrysanthams, 1s.; and flower-pots, 2d.; the goods of
Alexander Protheroe.
ALEXANDER PROTHERON . I live at Leytonstone. I had some plants safe on Sunday night, the 25th of April—one was in my green-house, two

were in pots out of doors, and several of them were planted in my garden—on the 26th of April I was called by the policeman, and I missed them—the greater part of them are here—I can swear✗to them as being mine.

WILLIAM POTTER (police-constable K 273.) On the morning of the 26th of April I saw the prisoner against Mr. Protheroe's fence—the gate was wide open—she was trying to conceal some of these plants under her clothes—she had got this camelia in her hand—these are the plants she had—one of these had been in the green-house, and she had it with her out of the green-house.

GUILTY .* Aged 50.—
Confined Six Months.

1287.
JAMES WHITE
was indicated for stealing 30lbs. weight of iron, value 4s., the goods of the
Eastern Countries Railway Company.

JOSEPH BENTON (Police-constable K 381.) I am stationed at Stratford. In Feb. I saw the prisoner and Henry Revel, coming up the Eastern Counties Railway—I watched them—they came to a wall five of six feet high, and Revel got over—White lifted a bag up, and Revel took it from him—they went into Stratford, and carried the bag—I watched them—they saw me, and tried to make away—I ran and stopped Revel, and took the bag from him—White made his escape—this is the bag—I am sure it is the same that White gave him—it contains iron bolts and pins—the prisoner had no business on the railway, nor to get over the wall—they could go a different way.

Prisoner. Q. Where was it you saw us? A. I was against a school, at the end of Great North-street—I watched them come up the line—when Revel got over, and White handed the bag, I walked up to them—they saw me and cut up Stratford—I stopped Revel, who has been tried, and White ran as hard as he could.

JAMES GALE . I am gate-keeper in the employ of the Eastern Counties Railway Company. I can identify these bolts and nuts as the property of the railway company—here is the Eastern Counties Railway mark on them—I am in the habit of receiving them at my gate—there is such property on the railway—they are using on the line daily—people watch the workmen away to their meals, and take these things—these are as good as ever they were.

Prisoner's Defence. The officer did not see me with Revel; I did not hand the bag; I was not on the line; Revel said he should like to do some
thing to get a month.

GUILTY .* Aged 19.—
Confined Two Months.

1288.
MARY ANN GILLHAM and
CHARLOTTE JACKSON were indicted for
stealing 1 watch, value 1l.; 1 shawl, 19s.; 9 yards of printed cotton, 4s.; 1 pocket-book, 2s.; and 1 box, 2d.; the goods of
Thomas Bakewell; and that Jackson had been before convicted of felony; to which

GILLHAM pleaded
GUILTY —
Confined Twelve Months.

THOMAS BAKEWELL . I am servant to Mr. James Hunt, of Sydenham. On the 4th of May, abont three o'clock, I missed from a drawer in my bed-room a shawl, a gown-piece, a watch, and a pocket-book—they had been safe at half-past two the same day—in consequence of information, I sent for a po
liceman, and showed me a gown-piece and shawl which I had lost—the watch and pocket-book produced are my property, and were in my drawers—I know this box.

THOMAS CAMPBELL (police-constable R 146.) In consequence of informa
tion, on the 4th of May, I went to Deptford, and traced both prisoners to a pawn
broker's—I went into the shop, and Gillham pledging the shawl—I took it from her—Jackson was in the next box—I saw her coming out with a small basket—I asked her if it was her property—she said, "yes"—it contained a small box—she said it was her own—the gown-piece was given me by the shopman in the prisoner's presence—he said Jackson had brought it there, and left it on the counter

SARAH AVELEIGH . I am the wife of a policeman—I live at the station, and search female prisoners. On the 4th of May the prisoners were brought in—I searched Jackson, and found a watch, rolled up in a handkerchief, in her pocket—I took it from her—she said that was the worst job of all.

JAMES PHIPPS . I am a coal-dealer. On the 4th of May, at half-past two or three o'clock, I went with some coals to Mr. Hunt's, Bakewell's master—I saw both prisoners about a hundred yards from the gate, sitting on the side of the road, talking together—I saw Gillham open the gate, and go in—Jackson walked about a hundred yards further, and stopped till Gillham came out—I saw her come out—they went down the road together.

(The prisoner Jackson put in a written defence, stating, that she went of with Gillham, who proposed that they should take anything they could find at the first house they came to; that she refused to join her in any such thing; that Gillham promised she would not do so, and then left her, and went to the house; that she did not wait for her, but walked on, and Gillham came to her with a bundle.)

JOSIAH VINCENT (police-constable R 16.) I produce a certificate pf Jack
son's former conviction—(read—Convicted Aug., 1844, and confined three months)—I was present at the trial—she is the person—she has been in cus
tody two or three times since.

JACKSON—
GUILTY .—
Transported for Seven Years.

1289.
LEAH WADMAN was indicted
for stealing 5 waistcoats, value 10s. the goods of
Edward Charles Carpenter Nash; to which she pleaded
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 37.—
Confined One Month.

1290.
MASON GEORGE HEMMINGS was indicted
for stealing 1 coal, value 3l. 15s.; and 1 pair of trowsers, 5s.; the goods of
Charles Alexander Miller; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 42.—
Confined Three Months.

1291.
JOSEPH BARTON and
THOMAS GARLICK were indicted for
stealing 7lbs. weight of mutton, value 6s.; the goods of
Frederick Reeve.

JOHN SAFFREY . I am in the service of Frederick Reeve, a butcher, at Greenwich—on the evening of the 23rd of April, about nine o'clock—I concealed myself in a garden opposite the shop, and saw the two prisoners walk past the fence on the opposite side to our shop—they walked up the hill and down again—then separated, and Garlick went down a turning—Barton went across to our shop, unhooked a leg of mutton, put it under his coat, and walked away—I walked out of the gate and took him—he denied that he had it—I took it from him—I do not know where Garlick was then.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. How long had you been watch
ing? A. An hour and a-half—it was quite dark.
JURY. Q. There was a light in the shop? A. Yes, that enabled me to see what took place.

JOHN SWAINE (police-constable R 325.) I was on duty, and saw the two prisoner together at the top of Royal-hill—I went down my beat, and in about a quarter of an hour I was called to take Barton, who was in custody of the witness, and the meat.

BARTON—
GUILTY. Aged 17.—Recommended to mercy.

GARLICK—
NOT GUILTY .

1292.
ELIZABETH EADE was indicted
for stealing 4 shirts, value 12s.; the goods of
James Mottram.

ELIZABETH MOTTRAM . I am the wife of James Mottram—we live at Woolwich—I take in washing—on the evening of the 13th of April some Shirts and other things hung out to dry, and I missed four shirts, which are now here.
WILLIAM CANT . I am shopman to a pawnbroker—the prisoner offered one of these shirts to me, and I stopped her with it.
GEORGE BARTON . I am pawnbroker—I produce a shirt, which was pawned by the prisoner.
Prisoner. I know nothing about them—they were given me to pawn.

GUILTY .* Aged 52.—
Confined One Year.

1293.
HENRY HUTCHISON was indicted
for stealing 1 truck, value 2l.; the goods of
William Wadley; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Three Months.

1294.
JOHN GLOVER was indicted
for assaulting
Henry Wadlow, a police-constable, in the execution of his duty.

WILLIAM THORN . I conduct the business of the Crown and Anchor Tavern, at Woolwich—on Friday, the 9th of April the prisoner and Dybell came into the house three times—they behaved very abruptly indeed, abused the people at bar, and very much "annoyed" the business—about five minutes after eleven o'clock at night we refused them any liquor, and they were going into the tap-room—I called the policeman to turn them out—he said he could not come into the house unless he saw an assault made—I

then desired the prisoner to walk out—he would not—he struck me and threw me against the wall in the passage—the policeman then came in and took the prisoner—Dybell then served me in the same way-the policeman took the prisoner out of doors—I did not see what happened to the police
man—Dybell gave bail, and has not surrendered.

HENRY WADLOW (police-constable R 267.) About eleven o'clock at night on the 9th of April, I was called to the Crown and Anchor—I heard there were disorderly persons inside, but I did not think it my duty, accord
ing to our instructions, to go inside—I then saw Mr. Thorn attempt to put the prisoner out—the prisoner took him by the collar and threw him against the wall—he then followed him, took hold of him again, and threw him on the table—I said I should take him into custody—he was very obstinate, but I succeeded in getting him outside—the moment I got him outside he hit me with his clenched fist in the eye, and knocked me down backwards, and commenced kicking me while I was down—he thrust his fingers into my throat and pressed my head to the ground—he very much hurt my throat—I had two black eyes—he fell on me with his knees on my cheat while I was down—I got on my knees and struck him with my staff—he knocked me down a second time and hit me in the eye—Dybell then came and kicked me in the side twice, while I was down—he then caught me by the thumb and pulled it back and very much injured it—I called for assistance while I was on my knees—I lost my senses, and when I came to my senses again the prisoner and Dybell were on me—I still had them by the collar—two civilians came and sprang my rattle—the prisoner was taken on the spot-Dybell made his escape, and was taken the next morning—I was unable to attend to my duty for five days, in consequence of the injuries I received—I was obliged to have medical attendance—I have been since put on lighter duty.
Prisoner. You were standing at the bar drinking—you had a pint of half-and-half. Witness. No, it is quite false.

Prisoner. It is true—I went in the tap-room and a man asked me to drink—the officer came and told me to go out—I said "I shan't till I have drank this pint and had another pint," and he struck me with his staff.

JAMES SULLIVAN . I am in the service of an eating-house keeper near the Crown and Anchor—about eleven o'clock that evening I heard the police
man crying out for assistance—I went out and saw the prisoner hit him in the eye with his hand—I ran up to lay hold of the prisoner, and he hit me between the two eyes—I got up again, and saw Dybell run up and kick the officer in the side, or in the back, while he was down—assistance came, and the prisoner was taken—Dybell got away.

HENRY EDWARD DRINKWATER . I am a surgeon—I act during the ab
sence of Mr. Stewart, the surgeon to the Police-force—I was called to attend Henry Wadlow—he had two contusions on his forehead—his right hand was considerably bruised and lacerated—the skin of the knuckles was torn off—he appeared like a man who had been severely beaten—he suffered in con
sequence of it for several days.
Prisoner. I never kicked him.

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined One Year.

1295.
GEORGE SMITH was indicted
for staling 1 copper goose neck of a fire-engine hose, value 8s.; the goods of
our Lady the Queen.

HENRY COOK . I am a corporal of Marines, on board the Growler—the crew of that vessel are now on board the Salsette hulk, at Woolwich, while the Growler is under repairs—the prisoner was a marine on board the Growler—on the 26th April in the evening, he had leave to go on shore, and I ob
served a bundle under his arm—I asked him what he had there—he said, "Nothing"—I said, "Let me look and see what it is"—I found in the bundle this piece of copper pipe, "goose neck" I believe it is called—it was in a shirt—here is the mark of he board arrow on it—I took the prisoner aft, and gave him in charge under the sentinel—the prisoner had gone away in a boat to work at the yard that day.
Prisoner. Q. Was the bundle tied? A. Yes, and you untied it.

Prisoner. I found this goose neck as I was washing myself; I said to my mate, "I will take it on deck;" I did so, and the Corporal said, "What have you got there?" I said, "Some dirty things;" he would not give me time to speak, but took me; it was not my intention to take it on shore.
Witness. You were half way down the ladder before I called you back—there was a boat to take you on shore.

THOMAS WELLS . I am master of her Majesty's steam vessel the GROWLER—the prisoner was stopped by Cook—it was reported to me, and I went on deck—I asked the prisoner where he got the article from—he said he picked it up on the lower deck of the vessel—it belongs to the dock-yard where the prisoner had been employed that day.

JOHN HARWOOD . I have charge of the fire-engines in Woolwich Dock-yard—this piece of copper pipe was brought to me by the police-constable—I examined the hoses of the fire-engines in the yard—I found a goose neck missing from the store-house engine—this goose neck will fit it—the engines are made with a universal screw, it will fit any one—there was one missing, and this would fit it—it is marked with the broad arrow, and D. Y. DAVID ROY. I am clerk in the dock-yard, at Woolwich—this is part of her Majesty's stores.

BENJAMIN FISHER (police-man R 272.) I am stationed at Woolwich—I was called on 26th April, about a quarter past seven o'clock in the even
ing, to take the prisoner in charge—I asked him where he got this from—he said he found it on the lower deck—I took him to the dock-yard gate—he was there charged—on conveying him to the station I said, "You are a foolish fellow"—he said he knew he was guilty, he could not help it—this is the goose neck.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

hi.rs: GUILTY. Aged 32.— Recommended to mercy by the Jury.—

div1.p:
1296.
JAMES ELLIOTT was indicted
for unlawfully having in his possession certain naval stores marked with the board arrow.

JAMES BURTON (police-constable M 272.) I was in Holland-street, near Blackfriars-bridge, on 24th of April, about nine o'clock in the evening—I was in plain cloths in company with Wild, another officer—I saw the prisoner carrying a bundle, which appeared to be heavy—I followed him to Mr. Kayser's shop in Great Guildford-street—he went into the front parlour—I

looked through the window shutters, and saw him take the handkerchief of the bundle—it was then tied in a white canvas bag—we then missed them from the window—they went into the back shop—we knocked at the door, and went in—I got a light, and saw the prisoner standing by the side of the anvil, in the back shop, with the bundle which I had seen before—I asked him what he had got there—he said he used to keep a shop at Westminster, and he worked at Wollwich, and brought this from the dock-yard—I had not at that time examined what was in the bundle—we then untied it, and found in it twenty-four bars of steel—I told him he must go to the station—in going down Guildford-street he begged of me to let him go, and said it was the first time he had ever brought anything from the dock-yard—he attempted to escape—I at last got him to the station—I searched him, and found on him three keys—the inspector asked him where he lived—he said at No. 16, Coleman-street, Woolwich—I went there, and one of the keys I found on the prisoner opened a kind of shed in the back garden, at a short distance from the house—in that we found a forge, and some other things, these five files and two copper bolts—I then searched a kind of closet, which is partly under the kitchen of the house, which I opened with another key which I found on the prisoner—we found in that closet a great quantity of steel which was new, but had no mark on it—there was 665lbs. weight of steel in that closet—I cannot say whether these two pieces of steel came from that closet or from the shed—this other piece is one of the twenty-four that were found on the prisoner at Kayser's—it is marked with the broad arrow—the steel in the closet was marked "Crowley, Millington,"

Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. Is this the first you have stated about the twenty-four pieces? A. No; it was said by me, before Mr. Trail, at Woolwich—the depositions were taken at Greenwich—I cannot say whe
ther it was stated when the depositions were taken—we had two examinations.—I do not know whether I stated it at the time I signed my deposition—no one had put me on looking after the prisoner—I had received no informa
tion to look for him—I have not brought the whole that we found, only what was marked with the broad arrow—this weighs about 30lbs.—the prisoner attempted to run away as I was taking him to the station—that was after he told me he came from Woolwich, and worked at the dock-yard—my brother officer was a little before me with the 6lbs. weigh of steel on his back, which was in the prisoner's bundle—I think he saw the prisoner run away—the place we went to at Woolwich was a small shed in a garden—it had a small forge in it—there was no appearance of a smith's-yard—it is a fruit garden—I believe the prisoner has some lodgers in his house—he said at the station, in my hearing, that he brought most of this from West
minister to Woolwich, some years ago, and that it had been in his possession some years—he did not give me his address while he was in Kayser's shop—he might give it my brother officer—I was searching the back part of the shop—I believe there was gas in the front—I could see the bundle in the window—I could not see when I went in—the back shop was dark.
MR. GODSON. Q. Was there a forge in the shed, large enough to wars iron, and take the mark out? A. Yes.

GEORGE WILD (police-constable M 94.) I was in company with Burto✗ on the 24th of April—I saw the prisoner going along Holland-street, with a bundle tied inn a check-handkerchief—we followed him to No. 27, Great Guildford-street—he knocked, and was admitted—we waited outside, against.

the shutters of the front room on the ground-floor—we saw the prisoner in
side, and the bundle was standing on a form about two feet high—it remained there some time, while the prisoner and the person in the shop were looking at some tools—there were some holes cut in the shutters, through which we looked, and saw them—Kayser's wife then went out, and we missed the pri
soner and another party from the room—we knocked, and a female came—we asked if Mr. Kayser was there, and said we wanted to speak to him—he came and admitted us—we went in, and found the prisoner in the back room, standing against the anvil—I asked Kayser where the parcel or bundle was that that gentleman had brought in—I looked, and it stood on the anvil—I asked the prisoner where he worked—he said, at Woolwich Dock-yard—I said, "Where did you get this"—he said, he brought it from Wool
wich Dock-yard—I said, "It is property you are not allowed to bring away by any means; you must consider yourself in custody; we are two police constables"—I took the steel, and Burton took charge of the prisoner—he said he was a respectable person, he had been in business, and it was a portion of his property when he was in business at Brewer's green, Westminster—I was a little in advance of Burton and the prisoner—I looked round and missed them—I went to the top of the street, and hallooed out, "Burton, have you got the prisoner?"—he said, "Yes, I have"—I said, "Hold him till I come"—the prisoner was taken to the station—a watch, and three keys, and 17s. in money, were found on him—he was asked where he lived—he said he rented a house at No. 16, Coleman-street, and was a respectable man—I went to that house, and with one of the keys found on the prisoner, Burton unlocked a shed, where we found a quantity of steel and tools, and these files—there was some steel piled up—I put my hand behind it, and found these copper bolts—I examined a closet-down under the kitchen—it was opened by another of the keys found on the prisoner—we went down five or six steps, and under part of the kitchen, we found in the closet an immense quantity of steel of the same kind as this, and such tools as stone
masons use—these files were found in the shed where we found the copper bolts—part of the steel in the shed had the broad arrow on it—the steel found in the closet was of the same kind.

Cross-examined. Q. Was there any part of this man's premises that you did not rummage? A. I should say there was—we did not interfere with the bed-room—we went through the kitchen, but did not examine it very minutely—we have brought five files, two or three pieces of copper, and two or three pieces of steel, which have got the broad arrow on them—the prisoner told us in the shop, that he lived at No. 16, Coleman-street, Woolwich—I then walked away—the prisoner and Burton were close to my heels at first—I then went to Burton's assistance, to catch the man who had given his ad
dress—I never had an Admiralty case before, nor a Mint case, or Cust
toms—I do not know what the Government allowance is—I do not know what I shall get—the prisoner said he had most of the steel when he was in business in Brewer's-green, Westminster, and that he took it to Woolwich—he said he was going to sell part of the steel he had at home—he did not tell me he was going to move—he afterwards said he bought the steel, and he could satisfy us where he bought it, but the person I think he said was gone abroad—he did not mention Mr. Branscomb, or Bedford, or Winter, or Rich—he never said a word to me whom he bought it of, but since he has been in custody his wife said something about bills.
MR. GODSON. Q. When did he say he bought it of a person that was

gone abroad? A. The same night, before he was charged—he said he could satisfy us he bought it, but the person was gone abroad—he said that about half-past nine o'clock, before the inspector took the charge—he first men
tioned about Westminster, in Kayser's shop, after he said he came from Wool
wich.

DAVID ROY . I am clerk in the store-keeper's office, in Woolwich Dock-yard. I know the prisoner—he has been employed in the steam-factory there—he was so in April—this copper bolt is the property of the Crown—bolts of this sort are never sold—here are three broad arrows on it—this piece of steel has the mark on it—on these files the broad arrow is obliterated—the maker's name is on them—I cannot distinguish the broad arrow on any of them, but I have no doubt it has been there—here is the place where it has been.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you know anything of the prisoner beyond pay
ing him his wages? A. I do not pay him—I know he was a mechanic in the Dock-yard—I believe he is a mechanic in his own yard—I saw a shed on his premises, and he had a forge—I know nothing of his being employed by his fellow-workmen in repairing their tools—the workman in the dock-yard use the Government tool, not their own,

COURT. Q. Are those pieces of steel made there? A. No, we get them supplied by contract—some of them come with the broad arrow on, and some without—they are marked, "Crowley, Millington"—he is the Government maker—he is a very extensive maker—on the files are, "John Tubb" and "Turton"—they are the Government makers of these.

THOMAS WRIGHT . I am a labourer in the Dock-yard, and lodge at the pri
soner's house, No. 16, Coleman-street, Woolwich—there is a garden at the back of the house, and a shed in it—I have seen the prisoner go into that shed many times—I never saw it open except when he was there—he un
locked it when he went in, and locked it each time when he came away—he left home about half-past six o'clock on the 24th of April.

Cross-examined. Q. What part of the house do you occupy? A. The lower room or kitchen—that is adjoining to the closet where these things were found—I never worked for the prisoner but on one occasion—he does work as a smith there—he is employed by his fellow-workmen a little—he works a little of a night—he repairs tools for masons.

Q. Is it fact that you have applied to the landlord to become tenant of that house in the room of this man, since his apprehension? A. I went to Mr. Sims, the landlord—I did not tell him they were going to transport Elliott on my evidence—I did not say, "I am the principal evidence against him—in the event of Elliott being transported, will you let me have the house?"—I do not know what I am to be paid for coming here to give evi
dence.

MR. GODSON. Q. Do you know the place where these things were found? A. Yes—there is another room parts that and mine—I never saw that place unlocked, unless Elliott unlocked it himself, and he always locked it after him.

JAMES SIMS . I am a builder, and live at Woolwich—I am the owner of several houses there—the prisoner has been my tenant for six years, since 1841—I have witnessed his character—one part of the yard which he occu
pies, I occupy for a building-yard—he carries on the business of a smith to some extent—he has been an industrious honest man—he has been at work

in the dock-yard since 1841—he has been part of that time employed by Grissel and Peto—he took the house of me in 1841—he came from some part of Westminster—I gave him notice to quit on the 25th of March, because I wanted to make some improvements in the house—I saw the witness Wright on Sunday, the 25th April—hecame to ask me whether I was aware that Elliott was taken as a prisoner—I said, "No"—I asked him what for—he stated, for having possession of Government stores—he asked me whether I would accept him as tenant for his house, and whether the shop which Elliott worked in, belonged to me—I stated that it did—he then asked me whether Elliot owed me any rent—I replied, he did—he said Elliot contem
plated taking the shop down—I said, "If Elliott takes it down, I shall trans
port him"—he said, "No, they will save you the trouble"—I said, "I have made use of hard words, but I will not allow him to remove it."

MR. GODSON. Q. Did you not give the prisoner notice to quit your house because it was being put in a bad character, by certain women frequenting it? A. I did not—I was not aware that women frequented it, only as lodgers—I am quite sure the prisoner was my tenant for the shed—it was fastened by a padlock, which he put on about five years ago—I have seen that shed open for days together—the prisoner was employed by Grissel and Peto, doing Government work in the yard.

GEORGE KAYSER . I am a smith, and live in Guilford-street. I have known the prisoner eight years—he bore a very good character while he was employed at the Parliament-house, and as a master for himself at Brewer's green, Westminster, where he had a shop to do mason's tools—after that I did not see him for some years.

COURT. Q. How long is it since he was at Westminster? A. Seven or eight years ago—I do not know at what time he went away—the policemen came and asked where he came from—he said he worked at Woolwich Dock-yard, and lived at Woolwich—I am not certain whether he told them at what place—he said he brought these things from his house at Woolwich—he said he had worked in Westminster before, where he was in business, and he had a quantity of steel by him that he wished to dispose of, because he was going to move from his house where he was living, and he wished to give up his shop.

MR. GODSON. Q. Have you had any steel with the broad arrow on it? A. No—if I had seen any I should know it—I did not expect the prisoner—he came accidentally to me that night—I had not seen the metal till the policemen opened it—I never saw the broad arrow on it—I saw them take two or three pieces out of the bag—I did not see any mark on them—if I had bough that metal I should have worked it into mason's tools—it is as good as other steel, it is the same as what we buy—I have seen Mr. Sims now—I did not know him before—I make a great many mason's tools—I buy steel of merchants and other persons that have it to sell—I have been to Woolwich once or twice—I have been in Coleman-street—I have known where the prisoner lived about two or three months—I was down at Wool
wich, about a week or nine days before the 24th of April—he had a good deal of steel in his smith's shop—I did not see any copper.

MR. PARNELL. Q. You did not think it was your business to rummage the shed and place? A. No—it is part of the business of almost every smith to purchase old steel and copper—they use it to make tools for themselves and others

CHARLES ROGERS . I am a boot-maker, and live at Brewer's-green, West
minster. I have known the prisoner thirty-seven years, in Somersetshire and in London—he lived with me at Brewer's-green—he was then a smith, as he

is now—I recollect his moving about six years ago—he had then a quantity of metal in his shop adjoining his house—I cannot say what quantity—I suppose he had several hundred weight—he has borne the character of as honest respectable man amongst his friends and neighbours—he has called on✗ me since he left me—I have never called on him.

MR. GODSON. Q. Are you any relation of his? A. No—he lived with me about two years—his business was making tools for masons—he had old and new iron rods—I used to see a great deal about—I did not take par
ticular notice of them—he rented the upper part of my house at 20l. a year, and had his shop adjoining—while he was at Westminster he was in the habit of making all the tools for Lee, of Westminster.

GEORGE BARNES . I live at Woolwich—I am a mason, and a contractor for the Board of Ordnance. I have known the prisoner eight years—he bore a very honest character—I never was in his shed—he is employed to make and sharpen tools there—he has sharpened picks, and axes, and other tools for me—he is in the habit of making tools of other persons.

MR. GODSON. Q. Name any other person for whom he has made tools? A. I cannot call one to mind just at present—at the time he was at West
minster he made tools for the masons that worked in the new houses of Parliament—I cannot call to mind any one for whom he has made tools at Woolwich—I am a contractor under the Board of Ordnance—they do not allow their workmen to carry on trade on their own account, that I am aware✗ of—I live about a quarter of a mile from the house where the prisoner lives, at Woolwich—I have been in his garden since he has been in custody—I went to pay his wife a bill for sharpening some tools.

MR. PARNELL. Q. Do you know Mr. Bell and Mr. Prentice? A. Yes—I know the prisoner has worked for Mr. Prentice—I am not sure whether he has for Mr. Bell—I have been employed by the Board of Ordnance—I am doing jobs for myself now.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 39.—
Fined 5l . and
Imprisoned Three Months.

1297.
EDWARD HOLTON was indicted
for stealing 2 shillings the monies of
Edward Batchelor:—2nd COUNT, stating them to be the monies of
Philip Langford.

MATTHEW M'GUIRE . I am a Greenwich pensioner. I met the prisoner on Saturday, the 1st of May—I went to a public-house and had a pot of the ale with him—I put half-a-crown on the table—the boy brought the ale and took up the half-crown—the prisoner got up and met the boy before he came back, and asked him for the change—he said the half-crown was his own—it was not his, it was mine.
Prisoner. Q. Did you put it down on the table or did I? A. I took it out of my pocket and put it down—I swear it was mine—you did not put it on the table.

EDWARD BATCHELOR . I am servant to Mr. Philip Langford, who keeps the public-house. I took the half-crown from the table and went for the change—the prisoner came out and asked me for the change of his half-crown—I did not know whose it was—I gave him the two shillings.
Prisoner. Q. Did I put the half-crown towards you? A. No—it was lying on the table—I did not know whose it was.

GUILTY .* Aged 21.—
Confined Two Months.

1298.
LOUISA DYER was indicted
for unlawfully attempting to kill and murder herself; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confired Five Days.

1299.
THOMAS DYER was indicted
for a like offence; to which he pleaded

GUILTY Aged—
Confined Five Days.

1300.
HENRY LOCK was indicted
for stealing 31lbs. of lead, value 5s.; the goods of
Henry Hunt Piper, his master; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

HENRY HUNT PIPER . I live at 42, Eastcheap—the prisoner was in my service at work at a building at Dulwich—a constable produced some edges✗ of lead to me which are mine—-the prisoner had no business with them.

JOHN HARRISON (policeman.) On the 19th of April, about twenty minutes to seven o'clock in the evening, I met the prisoner on Camberwell-green—I saw something bulky in front of his trowsers, stopped him, and asked him what it was—he said he had got nothing—I felt something, and asked him what it was—he said it was only a piece of lead which he had found—I took him to the station—I have fitted the lead to the building belonging to the prosecutor—it fits exactly—I found 31lbs. of lead on him altogether.

HENRY HUNT PIPER
re-examined. I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction—(read—Convicted June, 1839, of stealing lead, and con
fired six months)—I was prosecutor on that occasion, and am certain he is the man.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. I believe he has been twenty years in your service? A. More—I took him from gaol into my service again—he had 21s. a week, generally more—I had rather not say how he has behaved.

GUILTY Aged 33.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1301.
WILLIAM BUCKLEY was indicted
for stealing 39 pair of leather fronts for boots, value 4l.; 96 pairs of leather half-fronts for boots, 10l.; the goods of
John Poole and another.

WILLIAM POOL . I assist my father, John Poole, who is in partnership with my brother—we live at Walworth-common. On the 8th of Feb., at eight o'clock at night, I fastened up the shop—I was called by Harris about eight o'clock at next morning, and found the place broken open, and a quantity of leather fronts stolen—I had seen them there the night before—they were worth 13l. or 14l.—none of them have been found.
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Did you offer a reward of 10l.? A. Yes, next day.

JANE STOKES . I live at Bermondsey—I know the prisoner very well—two or three months ago, I do not know the date, he came to my house and brought a bag containing a quantity of fronts, grafts, and Clarences—I said, "I see you have got work"—he said, "Yes"—I said, "Where did you get it?"—he said, "From Mr. Batty, of Shoreditch"—I said, "I am glad of it, I hope you will keep it"—he went down stairs for five minutes, leaving the

goods at my place—I looked at the top of the bag—took up one which was at the top—it had the letter "G" on it—as nearly as I can guess from the bulk there were from seven to nine dozen—I do not know whether "G" was upon them all—I did not look at more than one—the prisoner came up stairs again—I said, "You smell of gin"—he said, "Yes, I have been drink
ing all the morning; I have cracked a crib, "by which I understood breaking a place open—I said, "Oh, my God! where?—he said, "Pool's—I said, "For God's sake, take them away"—I noticed a diamond on the bag, with the letters "B and S" on it—it was more dirty than the bag produced—it✗ was like a coal bag—it might have been such a bag as this, but blacker.

Cross-examined. Q. You knew what cracking a crib meant, why not go and tell the police? A. He was half tipsy, and I did not know whether it was true or not—I do not know now whether it is true or not—it is what he told me—I did not tell the police—I told the prisoner to take it away, that was all I wished—the policeman did not come and talk to me, nor did I give any information—I told my son about it, and it was him that gave informa
tion—he was not by at the time the prisoner said he had cracked a crib—he does not live with me—my husband was present, but he is deaf, he could not hear what was said—he was before the Magistrate on the first occasion, but was not examined, and on the second he had nothing to say—he is not here to day—all that he heard was the prisoner saying he had got work from Mr. Batty, of Shoreditch—he was sitting at his work about two and a half yards from the prisoner—I did not say when I was first spoken to about it, that I thought the bag had the letter "B" on it—I did not think anything about it—I said the leather had "G" on it—if anybody comes in with work we always look as it—I told him I had looked at the bag—my son was examined before the Magistrate—the police never spoke to me about this—my son spoke to me about it two or three weeks ago—I think it was this day three weeks that my son gave information about it to Mr. Pool—I and my son have not had a great deal of talk about this—I only told him about cracking the cirb—he went of his own accord to give information—I did not hear that 10l. reward was offered till this day three weeks, when I was at the Court—my son did not tell me of it before—I did not bring him here—I saw him here this morning.

GEORGE DYER . I am in the employ of Mr. Pool. On the 13th of Feb., when I went to work in the morning, I missed about eleven dozen of work in an apron similar to this one produced—it had the same mark as this, and a diamond—this is produced to show what it was like.
Cross-examined. Q. You have not found your apron? A. No.

WILLIAM MOSS (policeman.) I took the prisoner—I told him the charge—he said very well, he would come—Mr. Poole had sent for him—I told him the goods stolen were Clarence fronts, and some other things, and I under
stood he had offered some of the same description for sale to a Mr. Hoare—he stood he had offered some of the same description for sale to a Mr. Hoare—he said, "Very well; I am very much obliged to you for telling me what has been brought against me—he was told the charge again at the station, and said, "I never offered any for sale, and never had any in my possession."

Cross-examined. Q. Was Mr. Stokes, sen., examined on the first occasion? A. No—he was on the second—the son was asked a question or two—I believe there us a reward of 10l. to the paid on the conviction to the person giving the information.

WILLIAM POOL
re-examined. My boots had the letter "G" marked on them—the paper offering the reward did not say that they were in a bag marked "G."
NOT GUILTY .

1302.
JOSEPH SPIGNELL and
ALFRED DUCKETT were indicted for
stealing 1 brooch, value 4s., the goods of
Elizabeth Hurt, from her person; and that Duckett had been previously convicted of felony.
