ELIZABETH HURT . I am single, and live at St. John's-place, Walworth. On the 5th of April I went to the Surrey Theatre with some friends—I left about twenty minutes to twelve o'clock, and went into the parlour of the Equestrian Tavern, by the side of the theatre—after a short time I and another person left the parlour, and passed to the bar—the prisoners were standing together at the bar, but whether in company I cannot say—when I got to the street-door two females and a man stood there—I asked them to make way for us to pass—as we passed Spignell threw a glass of beer at my friend, but it did not touch her—he made a rush at her after that—he put the glass down, and said to a woman who was with him, "Give me my key"—that woman held her head down—I was passing at the same time, and he made a rush at me as I passed—I said, "That man has stolen my brooch"—he ran out at the side-door—I gave an alarm, and ran after him—I crossed the road—Duckett caught hold of me, and asked me what I wanted with that man, what I was going to do with him—I said, "The man has stolen my brooch"—he said, "You are not going to give him in charge for the brooch?"—I said, "Certainly I am"—he said, "What do you want with him? what are you going to do with him?"—I said, "I shall give him in charge"—he then laid hold of me, and threw me between the edge of the pavement and the road—my brooch was safe on my breast when I left the parlour—I had that moment fastened it, and I felt Spignell's hand at my neck

Cross-examined by MR. NAYLOR. Q. Had you a shawl on? A. Yes—I was not at all warm at the theatre—it was rather slack—the warmth of the par
lour made my friend's head ache, and she asked me to go into the street with her—I had not pulled my shawl off in the room—I left because the theatre was over—I was out of service at the time, and had been for two months—I did not hear a quarrel between one of the prisoners and a woman—he threw something over my friend, and said to the woman, "Give me my keys"—he went towards the woman to get the keys, and she held her head down—I do not know whether that was that he should not put his hand into her bosom—she was not trying to escape from him—I did not hear him swear—after that he went out of the house—it was about twelve o'clock—the woman did not say she would lock him up—I did not hear her say anything else—there was no confusion at all—I believe Spignell is an omnibus driver—there was no crowd in the theatre, it was very thin indeed—the woman did not give him the key—I followed him to the door—as I got to the door my handkerchief came undone, and I found I had lost my brooch—I had my sister with me—several people went into the tavern with us, a friend, and her husband, and Mr. Thompson—I was with him all the evening—he did not go to see us home—we had all been together that evening—my sister went to his house for him—there were seven of us altogether.

Duckett. Q. Were there many people in the house? A. I did not notice—you did nothing to attract my attention till the man threw something at us—it was you that stopped me crossing the road—I did not notice either of you till his happened—when you came up to me I was following Spig
nell—I had not been up the street—I had not been out of the house a mo
ment, merely crossing the road—the policeman fetched me to see if I was the

woman who had lost the brooch, as they had got the main in custody—they had taken him while you were holding me on the opposite side of the way, opposite the public-house—I was lying in the road—you had thrown me down, it was at the corner of the Blackfriars-road.

ELIZABETH GABITASS . I am the wife of William Gabitass, of Market-street—I was with the prosecutrix about twelve o'clock that night—I left the parlour of the tavern with her—in passing the bar I saw the prisoners—the proseuctrix asked one of the women to move to let us pass—Spignell took a glass with something in it from the counter and threw it—it went partly over me and partly over the bar—he said, "Take that," put the glass down again, made a rush at somebody who stood there, and, said, "Give me the keys, or I will knock your brains out"—he struck at the person—I got out of the way—I turned round to look after my friend, and Spignell had got his hand at her neck, where her brooch was—directly she got past them to the door she complained of her loss—Spignell ran across the London-road towards the Borough-road—I went out after the prosecutrix—I crossed, and thought she was with the policeman, but she was not—I went to look after her, and saw Duckett had got hold of her round the waist—he threw her down and ran towards the tavern again, and there the policeman took him—I had seen the brooch in my friend's shawl as we left the parlour to go out not two minutes before.

Cross-examined. Q. You had been to the theatre? A. Yes—I could not get a seat, and waited about the theatre some time—I saw the per
formance—I was waiting about from half-past nine till the theatre was over—I was looking at the performance part of the time—I afterwards joined my friends and went to the public-house—the prisoner seemed as if he was quarrelling with the person who stood right behind me—I think he intended to throw the beer over her, but it went on me, some of it—he seemed to✗ make a blow at somebody—I did not see whether he struck her—there was a man and a female talking to her—Spignell said, "Give me the key, I will not be played with, "and threw the glass at her—I do not know whether he hit her—I did not hear her cry out—she held her head down to avoid his blow, I suppose—I did not see her afterwards—there was a great deal of con
fusion—the bar was very full—there were a good many people drinking there—I do not know that there were many there till the cry of "Stop thief, "and of course then they all rushed into the public-house—I had never seen the prisoners before I saw Spignell's right hand on the prosecutrix's neck—after he attempted to get the keys he ran away—I do not know whether he got anything from her—the prosecutrix said, "Stop that man, he has rob
bed me"—I was not alarmed till she had been robbed.

Duckett. Q. Did you see me in the house? A. I saw you standing with Spignell—I cannot say whether you were drinking with him—I afterwards saw you crossing the Blackfriars-road, laying hold of my friend, and you crossed to the tavern again—she said to the policeman, "Stop that man, he has knocked me down"—I cannot say whether that was the policeman who took you—you were taken immediately.

COURT. Q. was there any confusion before Spignell produced it by throwing something out of a glass? A. No—I do not know whether it was a real quarrel, or whether it was merely done to draw my attention off—they were not near each other.
SAMUEL CROSS (police-constable M 83.) I was in the Borough-road, and heard a cry of "Stop thief"—I saw Spignell running with a crow after

him—I caught him, and said, "What are you running for?"—he said, "Let me go, I have only been striking a woman"—I took him back to the door of the tavern and made inquiry—I thought it was nothing but an assault—the mob rescued him form me—some one said, "Hook it," or something meaning "make off," and Spignell escaped from the public-house, through another door, into the Borough-road—I afterwards saw him in charge of another policeman, who also took Duckett—I took charge of Duckett—they were both taken to the station—the prosecutrix said Spignell had robbed her the mo
ment the policeman took him.

Cross-examined. Q. Spignell is an omnibus or cab driver, is he not? A. A cab driver—he works for Mr. Beard—I do not recollect his saying he did not want to be locked up all night—he said, "Let me go, I have only struck a woman"—he afterwards said he should not be able to attend to his duty, and it would the ruin of his family.

Duckett. Q. Was the cry of "Stop thief" in the Blackfriars-road or the London-road? A. At the top of the Borough-road—Blackfriars-road crosses the Circus—there was another policeman on the beat near me—there was no charge made against you at the time of stopping the woman—I saw you in the custody of the other policeman at the corner of the Borough-road—he gave you into my custody about seventy yards from the public-house, over against the cab stand.

GEORGE BATSFORD (police-constable M 70.) I heard a cry of "Stop thief!"—saw Spignell running, and stopped him—Duckett came up—I saw Spignell pass something out of his right hand into Duckett's left—I seized Duckett by the cuff of his coat—he swung his hands round to try to get away—I gave him to a policeman who came up at the time.
Cross-examined. Q. This was after Spignell had been in the custody of Croft? A. Yes.
COURT. Q. What does "Hook it" mean? A. To escape.

Duckett. Q. When you caught hold of me, what did I say to you? A. Nothing—I took hold of your right hand—I did not hear you beg me to search you—I gave you to Croft directly—if Spignell had passed anything to you I should not have seen what it was.

Prisoner Duckett to SAMUEL CROFT. Q. What did I say to you? A. That you did not know what you were taken for, and asked me to search you—you had nothing in your hand then—I took you five or ten minutes after the assault—I did not see the woman then—she came across, and said, "That is the man who took my brooch," and we went down to the station together—that was the second time I took you—I did not see anything of her the first time—Spignell was in custody when I saw her—the crowd at the public-house had called "Stop thief!"

Prisoner Duckett's Defense. The prosecutrix says she was going across the road when I knocked her down; there was no appearance of her being knocked down when she was at the police-court, or it would have been shown; I insisted upon being searched; the policeman held one of my hands; I held out the other, and said, "Is there anything in my hands?" and begged them to search me there, but they would not till I came to the station; if I had the property in my possession, should I have a skedhim to search me? is it likely, if the man ran away down the Borough-road with the brooch, that he would have carried the property, and then give it to me? the policeman says he took me directly he stopped Spignell; is it possible I could have been in the Blackfriars-road and insulted the prosecutrix, and asked her

the questions she says I did, and yet he in the Borough-road when I was stopped? when it is said Spignell ran as fast as he could all the way; expected a witness here who was in my company the whole time; I saw mob in the Borough-road, and went with him to see what it was; Spignell, who was in custody, said, "It is only a row; the policeman instantly said, "Why, you have parted with something to him;" I said, "It is no such thing;" the case is entirely got up by the policeman, on purpose that they should both have a charge.

JOSEPH HUGHFS (police-constable E 114.) I produce a certificate of Duc
kett's former conviction, from Mr. Clark's office—I was present at the trial—he is the person—(read—Convicted Oct., 1845; confined nine months.)

SPIGNELL—
GUILTY . Aged 35.

DUCKETT—
GUILTY . Aged 17.

1303.
JOHN SMITH was indicted
for stealing 1 piece of metal re✗
bling a shilling, value 1/2 d., the property of
John Thomas Willmore; and that he had been previously convicted of felony; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . —
Confined Twelve Months.

1304.
JONH HOBBS,
THOMAS FREDERICK WEBSTER , and
ROBERT LEWER , were indicted for
feloniously setting fire to a stack of hay, the property of
Frederick Piggott; and that Webster had been before convicted of felony.

FREDRICK PIGGOTT . I am an estate agent, and have a farm in the kew-road, in the parish of Richmond. At the back of that farm I had a hay-rick sixty or seventy yards from the high-road—on the 23rd of April, at a quarter to eight o'clock n the evening, I went round it, and saw it safe—at half-past eight, or a quarter to nine, I received information, which induced me to go to it again—I found it on fire, it was in a blaze all the way round—there were some faggots under it burning—it had been laid on faggots—with the assist
ance of some of my neighbours, I extinguished the fire—the faggots were burnt—it is impossible that combustion could be the cause of it, because it was old hay—I know nothing of the prisoners.

HENRY UPTON (policeman.) On the night of the 23rd of April I was on duty in the Kew-road, on the Richmond side of Mr. Piggott's hay-rick, about 200 yards from it—about five minutes after eight o'clock in the evening, and met the three prisoners going towards the premises, about 200 yards from the place—when they saw me they made a stop—two of then looked round, and crossed over the road—the rick was safe when I had passed it—in about twenty minutes I saw it on fire.

SAMUEL WINLET . I am a market-gardener, and live at Richmond. On the night of the 23rd of April, a little after half-past eight o'clock in the evening, I saw the prisoners in Sandy-lane—Mr. Piggott's meadow joins the lane—they were coming as if from the hay-rick—they were n the lane when I first saw them—at the time I saw them I noticed the hay-rick—it was on fire—they had their backs towards it—they asked me if there was an engine kept in the parish—I said, yes, there was—they came towards the cross road,

towards Richmond—I went towards the rick—in going from Sandy-lane into Kew-road they would not have to cross the meadow where the stack was (not where I met them,) but in getting from Kew-road to Sandy-lane they would—I had seen them at half-past two o'clock the same afternoon walking from Sandy-lane—they asked me where that road led them to—I know nothing about them.
Prisoner Webster. Q. When we met you in the afternoon did we speak to you? A. You asked where the road led; I said, "To Richmond," and you went that way—you were in company with the other prisoners.

KINGSTON MARK (police-sergeant.) On 23rd April I went to the place where the fire was, and afterwards went to the police-station and found the three prisoners there—I did not hold out any inducement or threat to them—they told me they wished to make a statement to me—that they had come to give themselves up for setting fire to the hay rick—I told them I was willing to hear anything they might have to say at the same time, I cautioned them that it would be taken down, and produced in evidence—I asked them if they were willing that I should take down what they said—they said, "Yes," and I did so—they were all three together—as one made a statement I asked the others if they agreed with it—they said, "Yes," and they all signed it—this is it—(produced)—I took their shoes from their feet—I saw footmarks near the stack, and compared those footmarks with their shoes in the direction they said they went, and found they corresponded.

The prosecutor's statement was here read, as follows:—"John Hobbs, a native of London, labourer; Thomas Frederick Webster, a native of London, labourer; Robert Lewer, a native of London, labourer; state, that between eleven and twelve o'clock this day, they came into Richmond by way of Kew Bridge; that they begged the halfpence to cross the bridge, and were the whole day in Richmond without anything to eat; that their lives for some time past had been spent in such misery and poverty, they were determined, when they left London this morning, to do something to alter it, and looked out for a stack to set fire to, About a quarter or half-past eight o'clock, as nearly as they can say, they climbed over the gate at the farm where the stack was set fire to (Mr. Piggott's); they all three went to the back part of the hay-stack; they then made three holes in the stack (by pulling out the hay so as to admit their arms as far as they could reach) one in the centre, the others at each end of the back part of the stack from the barn, when they all three lit lueifers from a pipe which Hobbs had, and set fire in the different holes at the same time; the side of the stack instantly was in a blaze; that they then ran away, and got through a gap of the hedge behind the stack, and then through another hedge by a gap into a ploughed-field, across this field, over a white gate, into a lane behind, (a road); then turned to the right at the top of the lane, and passed New Richmond into the main road; they then returned down the road and looked at the fire, where they stopped till the engine arrived, and then returned to Richmond, came to the police-station, where they gave themselves up. They also all declare, that they voluntarily make this statement, and that no promise has been held out to them; and that they have been properly cautioned that what they said would be taken down and produced in evidence against them.
"JOHN HOBBS ,
"THOMAS FREDRICK WEBSTER ,

Webster's Defence. My Lord and gentlemen of the jury: the offence of which I stand charged is one of a very heavy character, and which, I am very sorry to say, has brought me before your notice this day. My Lord and gentlemen, perhaps you will not credit what I am going to say to you; but I will fearlessly speak to you, convinced that I am innocent, and that what I am going to say is true. It is true that I was in Richmond during the day on which the fire occurred, and I also was the company of the other persons charged with me, and that I was also present at the fire; but I can assure your Lordship that the stack was not fired by me. But being reduced to the deepest distress, through the want of work, and not having tasted food for some time past, I was induced to accompany the other per
sons, and accuse myself of committing the crime, which has caused my friends a great deal of anguish and regret, that I had not applied to them for assis
tance. My Lord, I was never in the company of those persons accused with me, but on theday the fire occurred; nor can I, to my recollection, ever re
member seeing them before. the only thing that criminates me, is the marks which the officer states was made by the shoes which I wore; but I can assure you that they were not the print of my footsteps; for I never entered the field where the ground was capable of receiving any impression. My Lord, it is not at all improbable that the marks were caused by some person who assisted at the fire, and who, in the excitement of the moment, has not since remembered crossing the field. But, my Lord, I hope you will pause before you proceed to sum up the evidence adduced against me; for it would be doing me a great injustice without being convinced of my guilt; for the confession which I signed in an unthinking moment, and which has been used as evidence against me, which the keen pangs of hungers has induced me to put my signature to, is a falsehood, of which I have had reason to repent. My lord, taking all these considerations before your notice, and weighing the evidence brought against me, I may be led to hope for a favourable issue of my trial, and which I may be led to expect from an impartial and uncorrupted jury.

WILLIAM POCOCK (police-constable F 14.) I produce a certificate of Webster's former conviction—(read—Convicted June, 1844, and confined two✗ years)—I was present at the trial—he is the person—he has been convicted at this Court since that, and had three months—I proved the former convic
tion then.

WEBSTER—
GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Transported for Twenty Years.

HOBBS—
GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Transported for Fifteen Years.

LEWER—
GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Transported for Ten Years.

1305.
GEORGE WILLIAMS and
WILLAM HARRIS were indicted for
unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.
NOT GUILTY .

1306.
MARGARET SHEEN and
ANN SHEEN were indicted for
steal
ing, in the dwelling-house of
Edward M'Dermott, 1 ring, value 8l.; 1 neck chain, 15s.; 1 brooch, 10s.; 1 medal, 6l.; 1 seal, 1l.; 1 cloak, 3l.; 7 gowns, 4l.; 2 petticoats, 7s.; 1 sheet, 5s.; 1 blanket, 12s.; 1 wrapper, 12s.; 2 towels, 1s.; 1 pair of clogs, 6d.; and 1 locket, 10s.; the goods of
Alfred Driver, the master of
Margaret Sheen; to which

MARGARET SHEEN pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 19.—
confined Four Months.

ALFRED ERICER . I live at No. 63, Nelson-square, Blackfriars—the pri
soner Margaret was in my service—I went out on the 11th of April, leaving her there—when I came back she was gone, and the property mentioned also—she had been with me about three months—the articles produced are mine.

SARAH BARTON . I live at No. 63, Nelson-square—Mr. Driver lodges there—I went out on the 11th of April—Margaret Sheen had the charge of the house—I returned about eight o'clock that evening; she was gone, and I believe all these articles—I had seen Ann Sheen there twice—she was there on the 11th April, but she went out before me—I saw her and Margaret go up stairs towards Mr. Driver's room, and when Ann came away she had a bundle with her—she is Margaret's sister—I had seen her there once before.

ANN MACK . Ann Sheen came to me on 11th April, and dined with me—she went out, returned with two bundles, and said her sister had made her a present of them—I did not see what they contained—I saw some silk in one of them—this is the silk, and I saw a velvet cloak—the bundles were left at my house—I gave them to the officer the next morning.
JAMES BURTON (police-constable M 272.) I went to Mr. Mack's on the 12th April, and got these two bundles—they contain all the articles stated.

Ann Sheen's Defence. My sister came and asked me to come to her place, as she was going to leave; I went to fetch her things, not knowing there was any stolen property amongst them; she told me they were her clothes; I did not know any difference until I was taken into custody—if she will speak the truth she will tell the same.

ANN SHEEN.
GUILTY.—AGED 21.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury.

1307.
JAMES BENNETT was indicted
for stealing 4 bushels of oats, value 15s., and 1 sack, 2s.; the good of
Henry Dunkin, in a barge on the navigable river Thames.

DANIEL DAVIES . I live in King's-row, Horsleydown. I am a watchman to a brewery. On the 20th of April, about nine o'clock in the evening, I saw the prisoner and a man named Cook coming up a turning leading to Horsleydown Old-stairs—I knew of a barge of Mr. Dunkin's lying there—Cook was carrying a hat and a bag, and directly after him came the prisoner with a sack—I went to take hold of him, and put my hand on the sack—he dropped it, and Cook turned back and asked what I wanted to do, and showed fight—the prisoner got away, but was stopped by some persons—I took the sack which was in my fellow-servant's possession, and found the name Henry Dunkin branded on it—this is the sack, it is full of oats.
DAVID DAVIES . I was standing there—I heard the last witness call out "Police," and saw him seize the prisoner—I saw the sack on the prisoner's back—he dropped it, and I took it inside our gates.

MICHAEL MAHONEY (police-constable M 143.) I received charge of the pri
soner—as I was taking him along he asked me how I thought he would get on—I said I did not know, I knew nothing of the case—he said, "He did not see us take it, but he saw me with it"—I asked who was with him—he said, "Young Cook."
GEORGE TERRY . I am in the service of Henry Dunkin. He had a barge lying at that wharf—I took into it eighty sacks of oats on Tuesday evening,
the 20th of April—I left it about eight o'clock—I returned at nine, and missed one sack—this is it—the oats in it correspond, as nearly as possible, with this sample taken from the barge.
Prisoner's Defence. A man asked me to carry the sack, and put it on his cart.

DANIEL DAVIES
re-examined. He did not tell me that a man had employed him—he ran away.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Six Months.

1308.
JAMES FLANAGAN and
GEORGE ELDERKIN were indicted for
stealing 9 bagatelle balls, value 30s., the goods of
William Rogers.

SAMUEL WELLS . I am waiter to William Rogers, at the White Hart pub
lic-house, in St. Giles's—he keeps a bagatelle board—on the 24th of March the prisoners came there to play, in the afternoon, and went away again—they came again after eleven o'clock—I left them playing about half-past eleven—I was called away, and was away about seven minutes—I then returned, the prisoners were gone, and the gas was put out—on one else had been in the room—the nine bagatelle balls which had been there were gone—they have not been found.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. You went down to attend to the bell? A. Yes, on the first floor—the bagatelle balls were on the second flour—I had not been playing—I was standing there—there was no one playing but the prisoners—there had been several persons there, but they were all gone—no one else could have gone up without my hearing them
NOT GUILTY .

1309.
JAMES FLANAGAN and
GEORGE ELDERKIN were again indicted for
stealing 9 bagatelle balls, value 30s.; the goods of
Charles✗ Runey.

CHARLES RUNEY . I keep a beer-shop at Vauxhall. On the 1st of April the prisoners came there about four o'clock—they went into a room where I keep a bagatelle board—they asked where the balls were—I gave them two red balls and seven white ones—they called for a pint of ale—soon afterwards Flanagan came out for another pint of ale and a screw of tobacco—he took it into the room and shut the door—they were there some time, when a neigh
bour came and told me they had gone out of my window—I pursued them—they ran and I ran, but I lost them—when I came back my bagatelle balls were gone—no one else had been in the room.

FLANAGAN—
GUILTY . Aged 20.

ELDERKIN—
GUILTY . Aged 21.

1310.
RICHARD LETTS was indicted
for stealing 1 hat, value 1s.; 1 pair of shoes, 6s.; 4lbs. weight of beef, 4s., 1 loaf of bread, 4d.; and 1 to
bacco-box, 8d.; the goods of
William Cowland; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

WILLIAM COWLAND . I live at Pleasant Retreat, Brixton-hill. I am a brick maker—the prisoner came to lodge with me on the 27th of Feb.—he lodged there twp nights, and left just before four o'clock in the morning, on the 1st of March—I came down and missed my hat, my shoes, 4lbs. weight of beef, a 2lb. loaf, and a tobacco-pipe—no one else had been there—I found the prisoner in April, at the Three Goats' Heads, in the Walworth-road—he had my hat on his head—he had left his own hat on the table at my house—this is my hat.

prisoner. Q. How do you know it? A. By a place I broke in front of it—I have worn it for months—I can swear to it, but it was not in the condition in which it is now—the prisoner wore it a month or upwards before I found it.

prisoner. This hat I bought myself; there were lodgers in the house when I went out. Witness. They were in bed—there was only my son in the house, and one lodger, who has been with me three or years—I can swear the door was locked after the prisoner—I found it fast.

GEORGE EDWARD SPURRELL (police-constable 257.) I produce a certi
ficate of the prisoner's former conviction at Kingstom—(read—Convicted 19th Oct. 1841and confined twelve month)—the prisoner is the man.

GUILTY . Aged 35.—
Transported for seven Years.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

1311.
GEORGE WHITE and
GEORGE WILLIAMS were indicted for
stealing 68lbs. weight of lead, value 8s. 6d.; the good of
Edward Herring, their master.

JOSHUA GOLDER (police-constable M 87.) On the evening of the 27th of April I received information, and watched the premises of Mr. Herring, in Trinity-street, Southwark—about half-past seven o'clock I saw the workman leaving and saw the prisoners coming out with the others—they went down Trinity-street—I followed them down several streets to the Waterloo-road—I noticed White had something bulky about his person—he had a jacket on, and walked heavily—I called Brown—I stopped White, and saw something fall from Williams—I took White to the station, and found this lead on his per
son inside his trowsers, suspended to a belt round his loins, and there were two nails to fix it to the belt—I found on him a knife, some money, and a key.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you remain in the same street with White? A. Yes; William was turning the corner—I could see where he went to—he had not time to turn the corner—he passed the "per
pendicular" part of the corner—I saw him drop the lead, and a boy picked it up.

WILLIAM BROWN (police sergeant L 9.) I was on the spot, and Golder called my attention—I saw the two prisoners—I took hold of William at the corner of Baron's-building—I said, "You have some property about you that does not belong to you"—he unbuttoned his flap, and this piece of lead fell from him—I called a boy who took it up, it weight 38lbs.—the piece found on White weight 34lbs.—Williams had a belt.

HENRY DAVISON . I live in May's-building, St. Martin's-lane, and am a plumber—the prisoner were in my employ at these chemical works in Southwark—this lead is Mr. Harring's—it was on the premises there, I have no doubt—the prisoner, and all the men there, had access to it.
Cross-examined. Q. How many partners has Mr. Harring? A. I do not know—I believe none—I never said it belonged to him and his partners—this is my signature to this deposition.

Q. Here it says, "It belonged to Mr. Herring and his partners?" A. I was not aware that I swore he had partners—it was not my lead—I have seen lead on the premises—I will not swear that I have seen this lead there—I have seen lead there of the same quality, but not rolled up like this.

EDWARD HERRING . I do not know whether the prisoners were in my ser
vice I have no partner.
Cross-examined. Q. How came it to be reporter that you had partners A. I do not know—it is called "The British Alkali Company"—I believe this lead to be mine—I am the proprietor of the establishment.

WHITE—
GUILTY . Aged 33.

WILLIAMS—
GUILTY . Aged 23.

1312.
JOHN BORN was indicted
for stealing 1 pair of upper-leathers for boots, value 7s., 9 pairs of shoe-lasts, 4s.; 5 pairs of booth, 1l. 16s.; 2 pairs of shoes, 6s.; 72 pairs of leather soles, 50s.; and 21 lbs. weight of leather 10s.; the goods of
Edward Harris Rabbit, his master; to which he pleaded

hi.rs: GUILTY. Aged 32.—Recommended to Mercy.—

div1.p:
1313.
WILLIAM WARD was indicted
for stealing 1 shilling and 2 pence the monies of
Josiah Meredith; 1 handkerchief, value 1d.; 1 piece of copper 1d.; 1 penny, and 1 farthing; the property of
George Law; and that he has been before convicted of felony; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .* Aged 52.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1314.
CHARLES PHILLIPS was indicted
for stealing 1 handkerchief value 2s.; the goods of
Lewis Shrubsole, from his person; and that he has been before convicted of felony; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .* Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1315.
HENRY HURLEY was indicted
for stealing 1 handkerchief, value 5s.; the good of
Stephen Howell, from his person; and that he had been before convicted of felony; to which pleaded

GUILTY .* Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1316.
WILLIAM LANE was indicted
for stealing 3 pairs of booth, value 1l.; the goods
Henry Muggeridge; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

JAMES HILLS . I am assistant to Mr. Henry Muggeridge—he lives Tooting—I saw some booth safe on a board outside his shop, on the 24th April, about the middle of the day—I missed them about four o'clock—the are them, they are marked, and are my master's.

THOMAS NEWMAN . On the 24th of April I was walking near Mr. Mug
geridge's shop, and saw the prisoner with these three pairs of boots under his arm—I went into the shop, and inquired if he had bought them—they said, "No"—I went after him, and fetched him back to the prosecutor's shop with the boots.

JOHN FENN (police-constable, R 320.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction at this Court, by the name of John Brown—(read—"Convicted the 15th of Dec., 1845, and confined nine months ")—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY .* Aged 17.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1317.
THOMAS COOK was indicted
for assaulting
Eliza cook, with in
tent, &c.

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Two Years.

1318.
WALTER GRIGG and
GEORGE AUSTIN were indicted for
stealing two loaves of bread, value 10d.; the good of
Richard Trew, from the person of
Charlotte Trew.—2nd COUNT, stating them to be the property of
Charlotte Trew.

GRIGG pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 17.—
confined one month.

CHARLOTTE TREW . I am the daughter of Richard Trew. I live at Wim
bledon, with my father and mother—on the 6th of March, I was at the bottom of the White houses, at Wimbledon, about half-past twelve o'clock—I had my little sister Eliza with me—I was carrying four half-quartern loaves home—the prisoner Grigg came up to me—Austin was about twenty yards behind me—he was near enough to hear what Grigg said—Grigg said, "what have you got?" he pulled my apron open, and snatched out two loaves—I said, "Grigg, I know you"—Austin said, "Do not take it, she knows you"—Grigg ran to the back of the white houses—the groom ran after him.

JAMES ROOTS . I am groom to Mr. Wilson. I came up, and Charlotte Trew was crying—Austin was standing there—Grigg ran down a turning—I ran to take him, but he got off—he had no bread then—the policeman came up—showed him which way the boy ran, and he saw the prisoners and another sitting in valley—we went and brought Austin—Grigg ran away—the policeman brought him off the farm, and he showed us where they had put the bread.
EMANUEL STOCKLEY (police-constable V 291.) I found the prisoners—Austin said, he never touched the girl, and had nothing to do with it.

AUSTIN—
NOT GUILTY .

1319.
JAMES SMITH and
GEORGE ANDERSON were indicted for
stealing 1 iron shaft, value 3l.; and 1 iron wheel, 1l. the goods of
Charles kneene and others—2nd COUNT, stating it to be 378lbs. weight of iron.

BENJAMINE NICHOLLS . I am in partnership with Mr. Charles Keene and Christopher Nicholls—we have a manufactory in Granby-place, York-road, Lambeth—the way to it is through a pair of gates, through a passage, and then through another pair of gates to a yard, formerly in possession of Mr. Baker, which has been lately bought by the south-Western Railway Com
pany this piece of iron was a shaft—it is our property—I ordered it to be placed in that yard—it was taken out of the store, and left in the vacant ground about the 8th or 10th of April—I think I last saw it safe on Thurs
day afternoon, the 15th of April, and on the Monday following I missed that and a packing-case—in consequence of what I heard, I endeavoured to discover where the packing-case and shaft were gone—I went to the premises with an officer, from there to a field, and from thence to the back of a house, some distance off, where I found the packing-case—I saw the prisoner Anderson there—I asked him where the shaft was—he declared he did not know, neither had he seen it—I told him what shaft I meant, and asked him four or five times, and he constantly denied it—the officer, John Ould, was with me—I went the next day to Mr. Knowlden's, in Guildford-street, and the shaft was shown to me—I am quit sure it was mine—Anderson was afterwards brought to me in custody by Ould—Anderson said it was a bad job, he hoped I would let him go for that night, it was half-past nine o'clock, and he

wished I would not give him into custody, as he said got important papers and keys which he wished to give up to Mr. Dalrymple, his employer—he said he would be there by nine o'clock in the morning—the shaft is worth 3l. or 4i.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Do you know a person of the name of Ashlin? A. Yes; I do not know that he was employed on those premises—I have heard so—Anderson admitted that the packing-case had✗ been removed by him, and gave a reason for removing it; but with reference✗ to the shaft, he said he had nothing to do with removing it.

Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. Ashlin is an engineer? A. I do not know—he is foreman of the Lambeth Water-works Company—the South-Western Railway Company got possession of these premised three or four weeks before that time—there had been nothing sold by auction on the pre
mises, but a great many things had been removed—there was no confsi✗ at all—this shaft was partly on the South-Western Railway premises and partly on our—no one could get it without the key to go us✗ that yard—we had one key—a man who had a stable there had a key, but he gave his key up, and a stone-mason, that had been in the yard three or four years, had one—I do not know Oakes, I have seen him, and he said he had command to remove those things that were on the premises of the✗ South-Western Railway.

MR. METCALF. Q. Were these things sufficiently on your premises to✗ indicate that they belonged to your warehouse? A. Yes; quite so—the shaft was leaning against the wall of our premises—anybody would has✗ assumed that it belonged to our warehouse—I went to the garden and was✗ Oakes there—Anderson afterwards admitted that he gave orders to Oakes to✗ remove it.

JOSEPH ASHLIN . I am foreman to the Lambeth Water-works Company. I have know the prisoner some time—I have known Anderson but a short time✗—On Friday, the 16th of April, I was working in Granby-place, taking up some water pipes, and Anderson came to me with some keys in his hand—he asked me if I would step a little way him—he took me to a gate which had a padlock on—he said on the way, that he wanted to point out to me where the thieves had been breaking in—he pointed to this piece of iron that as✗ there, and said, "They will have that before morning," and he asked if I knew in what way he could get it removed—I said, "I do not know, indeed"—he said, "Are you going to remain here all day"—I said, "Yes,"—he said, "Perhaps you will see some one who will move it"—in going back we met✗ Smith, and asked him if he would remove it—he said, "Yes," and Anderson gave him instructions to remove it—it was a round piece of iron—I did not take notice of it—we went together and Smith said, "Is this it?" Anderson said, "Yes"—Smith then said, "We had better have a drop of something to drink"—I did not see anything more of the iron—I afterwards saw Jones✗ and Parsons came running to their work—I asked them, where they had been—they said, to help a man with a piece of iron.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. While you were drinking, you men were running away with the piece of iron? A. It was some time after that I saw the me—I would not have sanctioned it—my men told me they gaw✗ it a lift—I was not at that time drinking in the public-house, I was with any✗ men—I was not in the public-house a minute—I do not know how Smith could say in truth that I gave him the iron to sell—what I have stated is the truth—I heard Smith say in the Police-court that I was the person who led

him to where the iron was—I was rather uneasy about this matter—I was 150 yards off—I was not there when the iron went away—after the state
ment were all given in I had a chat with Ould—I did not ask him to call at my house—I might have said, "Perhaps you will give me a call before you go to the Court"—I might have said that word to him—I will not say whether I did or not—I wanted to see him for a particular reason—because he made an omission in his statement before the Magistrate—I did not ask him to tell that on the second examination—he might do as he thought proper—he did not call at my house, to my knowledge—I never saw him there—he has been to my house with Anderson—he did not call after my observation to him—when I said he might give me a call, it was one evening in the York-road, by the Rising Sun—I did not hear that he had called after that—I do not know that he was treated at my house—I am not know
ledgeable of his having anything to drink at my house—I have never heard it.

Q. What was it the policeman omitted to say? A. He omitted saying that Anderson said, "Ashlin, I am done for, for Gods sake intercede with the policeman to let me go until the morning"—I said, "You have been an officer, you know better than that; if this man gives you up, he is liable to lose his situation"—I did not want anything set right—I had no object at all—I am nor the prosecutor of this indictment—I am not supplying any of the funds—I do not know who is—I never had a key to this yard.

Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. Anderson asked you if you could get him some one to remove this iron? A. Yes, that occurred in the yard where the shaft was—he had previously pointed out the shaft—I did not know exactly on whose premises it was—it might belong to the Railway Com
pany—my two men went to help in putting it on the truck—Anderson and I had a drop of gin together—I do not know what Smith had, it was something in a pot—my men are named Jones and Parsons—this happened about one o'clock in the day—Oake is porter to one of the auctioneers who had been selling the property—I was not aware whether Oakes had been helping the iron into the truck—I was not there—the public-house is about fifty yards from the yard—I think the gates were left open—there was not any one in the yard when we were in.

JAMES MILBURY . I am in Mr. Nicholls' employ. I was in the stable in Mr. Baker's yard, which adjoins Mr. Nicholls' premises, on that day—I saw a shaft of iron in the yard—I saw five men go and take it out—they were Smith, Parsons, Jones, Oakes, and a boy—they brought it out, put it on the truck, and took it right away—Smith assisted in dragging the truck.

JOHN KNOWLDEN . I live with my father, who is an engineer, in Great Guildford-street. On the 16th of April Smith came to me with some old iron, a piece of a shaft, and a rigger—he offered it for sale for 8s. a cwt.—I offered him 7s. 6d., which he agreed to take—he took some old iron, and paid me the difference—I showed that shaft afterwards to Mr. Nicholls.

JOHN OULD (police-constable L 87.) I was called by Mr. Nicjolls—I went to a garden, and found a packing-case—Anderson was there—he deniced seeing the shaft—I saw the shaft at Knowlden's—I took Smith into custody—he made no reply at first, but he afterwards asked me who gave me infor
mation—I said I found it out by making inquiries—Milbury afterwards came, and identified him as the man he had seen with the truck and the shait✗—next day, on the way to the station, Smith said he bought it of a man whom he knew two years ago, but he could give nodesription of his name or address—on the 25th of April, I took Andreson—I said I wanted him re
specting an iron shaft—he said, "Ashlin is as deep in the mud, as I am in the mire"—I forgot myself at the examination before the Magistrate, but when we got to Ashlin's, Anderson said, "What a pretty mess you have brought me into, you have done this to screen yourself; you are as deep in the mad✗ as I am in the

mire"—he said he thought it hard to be locked up, and not Ashlin—Ashlin said, "You know you have been a constable yourself, and if the constable gives you up, he may leave his situation"—after we left Mr. Ashlin, Anderson said he would split about it to-morrow—I said, all we wanted was the truth—he asked me to go to Mr. Nicholls'—we called there, and he begged and prayed of Mr. Nicholls to let him go—he said he was a constable, he had got keys and papers to deliver up, and he would appear any time to-morrow that was necessary.

Cross-examined. by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You did not happen to remem
ber some things on the first examination? A. I have not so good a head
piece as some people—I mentioned about his "slitting" the second time, not the first—I do not know whether Ashlin was uneasy about my forgetting it—he said I had mistaken it—I called at his house, but I did not see him—he was not at home—I saw a person, I do not know whether it was his wife or not—she acted like a domestic woman—I believe I had some ale—I did not pay for it—that was the day before I went to the Police-court, and then the next day I told about the "splitting," and about the mud and the mire.

Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. Smith is a dealer in old iron? A. He is a collector of it—he said at the station, after the charge was written down, "What, am I charged with stealing it?" MR. METCALF. Q. How much ale had you? A. One pint.

HENRY BATEMAN HODSON . I am assistant surveyor to the London and South-Western Railway Company. they are extending their line from Nine✗ Elms—they have lately bought this yard, of Mr. Baker—Anderson was in the employ of the Company—he had authority to remove iron, or lead, or any stores belonging to the Company, to a place of safety, or into empty houses, where he could lock them up, and where they would be secure.
MR. BALLANTINE to JOSEPH ASHLIN. Q. Did you go to an attorney's office for Smith, and instruct him to appear on his behalf? A. No; I went to a solicitor on my own behalf.
COURT. Q. What time did Anderson come to you? A. At past twelve o'clock in the day.
COURT to JAMES MILLBURY. Q. What time did Smith come with the others to take these things? A. I think it was after dinner, a little after two o'clock—I did not see Anderson.
NOT GUILTY .

1320.
JOHN ROBINSON was indicted for
stealing 50lbs. weight of iron, value 7s., the goods of
James Little and others; and
JAMES GUTTERIDGE
for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen.

THOMAS WEST (police-constable M 249.) On the evening of the 23rd April, about a quarter before nine o'clock, I was in Wellington-street, Dock-head,—I saw Robinson coming in a direction from the Greenwich railway with a quantity of hoop iron on his shoulder—I followed him to the prisoner Gutteridge's ware-house, in Jacob-street, Dock-head—he threw the iron down at Gutteridge's warehouse door—he then went to Gutteridge's private house, about three doors from the warehouse—he went inside, and staid about two minutes—Gutt
ridge then let him out—he fetched the iron from the warehouse door, and Gutteridge let him into the private house with it—he remained there about five minutes—I then saw him come out without the bundle—he went on, and

I passed him under a gas-lamp—he was in the act of counting money—he went on, and I followed him to the King's Arms public-house—Whitlamb there spoke to him, and asked if he had taken any iron to Gutteridge's—he said he had, and he fetched it from the foundry, by the King and Queen, Rother-hithe—(that was a different direction to that in which I had seen him come)—I took him into custody, and handed him to a constable on the beat—we went to Gutteridge, and asked him if he had sent a man to the foundry—he said, "No"—I asked if he had bought any iron—he said he had, about a week ago, of a man with a smock frock—I asked if he had bought any iron since—he said he had not—I asked if he had received any that day or night—he said he had not—I said I should search the place—I went through to the back door, and opened it—I saw the bundle lying at the door—I said, "Mr. Gutteridge, here is some iron here"—he said, "That is the iron I bought a week ago"—I searched, and found no other iron—I believe that was the iron that Robinson had had—I then took Gutteridge to the station—I saw Robin
son there—I asked Gutteridge if that was the man he had seen a week ago—he said he believed it was—before we took him he said he had bought the iron of a man, and gave him 1s. 6d. and a pint of beer, and the man asked him more than old iron price for it—that he bought it of a short man with a smock-frock on.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Had Robinson a smock-frock on? A. Yes.

JOHN WHITLAMB (police-constable M 89.) I was with West, on the evening of the 23rd of April—I saw Robinson coming from Dock-head with this bundle of iron hoops—I followed him, till he laid them down at the door of Mr. Gutteridge's cooperage—I then saw him go to the door of Mr. Gutteridge's residence—the door was opened—he went in, and came out, picked up the iron, and I followed him to the door and saw Mr. Gutteridge standing with a light—I afterwards went there with West, and found a bundle of iron in the back yard—to the best of my belief it was the same I had seen before—I was at the station when the prisoners were there together—I heard Gutteridge say, he believed Robinson was the man that wore the smock-frock that he had the iron of a week ago—Robinson had a smock-frock on.
Cross-examined. Q. I believe the Magistrate said it was a case fit to be inquired into, and held Gutteridge to bail? A. Yes.

JEREMIAH LYON . I am a watchman, belonging to the South Eastern Railway Company, near the Greenwich line—I am servant to James Little and Sons—I have seen this bundle of iron—they had such property on their premises—one of the sons died lately, some time before the 23rd of April—they had a quantity of this hoop iron for some months before the 23rd of April—I have seen it frequently—I had seen it in the early part of that night—I did not miss any till I was asked by the policeman if I missed any—I know Robinson.

JOSIAH WILLIAM BROWN . I am foreman to Messrs. James Little and Sons—one of the sons died lately, but there are now two sons and the father—they are partners—one of the sons is the principal person in the business, in fact he may be called the only contractor for this property—this belongs to them.

Cross-examined. Q. Has not one of the sons died lately? A. Yes, about two months since, but there are two sons now living—they are partners with the father—the business is always known in the name of James Little and Sons.

COURT. Q. What is the value of this iron? A. Seven shillings—it is not old iron—it weighs half-a-cwt.—I should say that a cooper who is in the habit of using iron would know old iron from new—this has never been untied.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Suppose it were old iron, what would be the value of it? A. I do not know—I only know the value of new—this had been on our premises I suppose for two months—it came from Hill and Perry's, is Whitechapel.
(The prisoner Gutteridge received a good character.)

ROBINSON
GUILTY .—Aged 49.—
Confined Three Months.

GUTTERIDGE—
GUILTY. Recommended to mercy by the Jury.
Confined Four Months.

1321.
JOHN WILLIAMS and
HENRY DAWSON were indicted for
stealing 1 coat, value 25s., and 1 pair of trowsers, 10s.; the goods of
James Digby; and that they had been before convicted of felony.

JAMES DIGBY . I keep a shop in High-street, Wandsworth—I had a coat and a pair of trowsers safe at seven o'clock in the evening on the 20th of April, and I missed them from my front shop afterwards—these are them.
JOHN MONKTON (police-constable V 197.) I found this coat and trowser on the prisoner Dawson, on the 20th of April—Williams was in company with him when they were given into custody.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Which of the prisoners did you see first? A. Williams—Cox had hold of him—Dawson was about two yards off—he was brought back by two other persons, who said, "This is the other man"—there were twenty people assembled—I had heard a cry of "Police," and went up.

THOMAS COX . I am a plasterer—I live in High-street, Wandsworth. Ah half-past eight o'clock in the evening, on the 20th of April, I was sitting at my window, and I saw the two prisoners come up the town—they stood about the prosecutor's shop—Williams went in, and Dawson stood a little way below—a constable came by, and Dawson went up and gave Williams a nudge on the elbow—the officer passed by, and then Williams went into the shop again, and came out with something on his arm, and Dawson joined him.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Where were you? A. Sitting up at my window, on the opposite side of the street, about twelve yards off—I looked down on the prisoners—I had not seen either of them before—I fol
lowed them—I had not lost sight of them above five or then minutes.
Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Did you see the coat on the prisoner Dawson? A. Yes, I saw it take off his back at the station—he had three coats on.

JAMES DRISCOLL (police-sergeant C 2.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner Dawson's former conviction at Clerkenwell, by the name of James Thomas—(read—Convicted 6th of Oct., 1845, and confined one months)—he is the person.

JOSEPH HUGHES (police-constable E 114.) I produce a certificate of Williams's conviction at Clerkenwell, by the name of William Steven—(read—Convicted 25th of March, 1846, and confined six months)—Williams is the person—he has been twice summarily convicted since.

WILLIAMS—
GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Transported for Seven Years.

DAWSON—
GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined One Year.

1321a.
ARTHUR HARGIN was indicted
for stealing 1 watch, value 2l.; 1 watch-guard chain, 2s.; 1 half-sovereign, and 2 sixpences; the goods of
Thomas Parker, from his person.

THOMAS PARKER . I came from Hull, in Yorkshire—I was living at Peter's-hill, Doctors' Commons. On the 17th of April, I was going over Lon
don-bridge, I was spoken to by a person, and in consequence of what he said I went to a house in King-street, Southwark, No. 4, I think—I went up stairs with him—I saw the prisoner in the room up stairs—the prisoner introduced this piece of satin—(looking at it)—he asked me to purchase it—he said it was valued at 30s.—I told him I had not the money to purchase anything of the kind—he came down to 6s., and I purchased it, with the idea of clearing out of the house—while I was paying for it, this shawl (looking at it) was introduced—the prisoner opened a chest in the room, and took it out—he said it was valued at 17l.—I told him I had not 17s. by me, I could not Purchase anything of the kind—he asked me if I would show him my watch—I pulled it out, and showed it him—after he saw that, I told him how much money I had—he would not believe me, so I pulled my money out, and showed it him—I had one half-sovereign and three sixpences—he took the half-sovereign out of my hand, and two of the sixpences, and left me one sixpence—he had put the shawl into my hat, and I had thrown it out two or three times, and put it on the table—he then unbuttoned a button of my waistcoat, and took my watch out, and while I was looking at it he slipped the guard over my neck.

COURT. Q. Had you given him authority to take that watch, either directly or indirectly? A. No; it was only through fear—the stair-foot door opens by a spring—the prisoner told me if the door was fast when I got below, I was to give three knocks, so (and he gave three knocks, rather loud)—I ran down stairs as fast as I could, and the door was wide open—I gave information, and saw the prisoner two days afterwards—I did not part with my watch willingly—I have the key of it in my pocket, and I should have given the key if I had parted with it willingly.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. what age are you? A. I am twenty-three years old—I was a truck man or car man in Hull—there was some in
timationthat these things were smuggled—this is the silk and the shawl—this all passed in the presence of the other man; and he kept talking to me, and told me I must make a good bargain with this man, as he was drunk—he made a number of different remarks—my watch was worth about 2l.

HENRY BARRY (police-constable M 171.) I met the prosecutor in the street, on the 17th April—he told me he had been robbed of his watch—I looked after the prisoner—I found him on the 19th of April, and took him into custody—he was pointed out to me by the prosecutor—I told the prisoner he must go to the station with me, for robbing this man✗ of his watch—he said, "Very well, I will go with you"—he went a little way, and he took some-thing out of his pocket and attempted to hand it to another man—I did not choose that—I took his hand, and we had a fight—I got him to the station, and found a number of duplicates in his hand.
Prisoner. If I had been guilty of anything of the kind. the prosecutor would have given me in charge in the open street.

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1322.
JAMES DORE was indicted
for embezzlement.

JOHN SIMPSON . I am a ginger-beer and soda-water maker—I live in King's-place, Newington—the prisoner was in my service—it was his duty to take money and bring it to me when he came home at night—if he re
ceived the sums in question he ought to have paid them to me on the days he received them.
Prisoner. When you cast up my wages on Saturday night you said, "You have had so much money of me, "and deducted it. Witness. No, I did not.
Prisoner. I never received this money—I always gave receipts.
EDWARD FRANCIS . I paid the prisoner 1s. for Mr. Simpson, on the 3rd of April—I have no receipt for it—I paid ready money.

HENRY WILLIAM BARTON . I had a dozen of ginger-beer, and three bottles of soda-water of the prisoner—I paid him 1s. 10 1/2 d. for it—I did not pay him at the time I had it, but I am quite sure it was paid—I am not indebted to Mr. Simpson for anything.
Prisoner. You were not at home; your wife took them in, and said, "When my husband is in the way, he will pay you. Witness. I am well aware of that, but I paid you the next day when you called.
COURT. Q. Are you sure you paid him? A. I would not swear it, but I believe I did.

HENRY BUTTLE . I had six bottles of lemonade, and six bottles of soda-water from the prisoner—my wife paid him in my presence—I gave her the money—I cannot say on what day it was—there was a receipt given for it, but it is lost.

Prisoner's Defence. I have been about the town for Mr. Simpson for fourteen months; another person set up in the business; he heard of me, and offered me 5s. a week more than I had of Mr. Simpson; I said I was satis
fied, I did not want to change; this is done out of spite, because the other gentleman wished to get me away.
NOT GUILTY .

1323.
JAMES DORE was again indicted
for stealing 12 bottles, value 1s., and 3 quarts of ginger-beer, 1s. 6d.; the goods of
John Simpson, his master.

JOHN SIMPSON . On the 3rd of April I received information that the pri
soner was taking out more goods than he accounted for, and on the 4th of April I watched him, and saw that he was doing so—I told the inspector—he told me to watch him on the following morning, and I did—I saw the pri
soner and the foreman put the goods into the cart—the prisoner took the cart into the street—it was then taken to the station, and I found in it one dozen more than the prisoner had accounted for—he had done it by a very novel mode of packing—in the bottom tier of the crate he had managed to put four dozen and three bottles, four dozen and three in the middle tier, and in the top tier only four dozen—the officer found that also, and in consequence of that I gave him into custody.
Prisoner. When the crates were empty we went to the stock of beer and filled them; when they were full we thought there were twelve dozen; we never counted them.

CHARLES MANN . I drive for Mr. Simpson. I took out the boxes with the Prisoner—they ought to have held four dozen in each tier—he ordered me to unpack one box that we did not sell, and there were six bottles over—I told him it was wrong, and I would not allow it while he was out with me—he said it was all right, it was only six over.
Prisoner. Q. Did they go back to the factory? A. Yes, but then he took the money—we took out three boxes, and there were six over in each.

JOHN WRIGHT (police-constable M 63.) I saw the prisoner, on the 5th of April—I took charge of the two boxes of bottles—I found fifty-one bottles in each of the two bottom tiers, and forty-eight in the other—there were six more bottles than there ought to be.

JOHN SIMPSON
re-examined. He brought these bottles back as if he had not sold them, when he had sold others instead of them.

Prisoner. I borrowed to loans of 20l. for him—I borrowed them for my master—I am answerable for it—here is the letter sent to me about it—he said he would do everything to serve me. Witness. I am answerable for it, not him—I am to pay it back by instalments.
COURT. Q. How came the man to borrow money for you? A. I was short of money—it requires one person to borrow it, and another to be security.
NOT GUILTY .

1324.
WILLIAM WESTON
was indicated for stealing two same rab
bits, value 4s.; the goods of
JANE WEBB; and that he had been before con
victed of felony.

JANE WEBB . I am the wife of John Webb—we live at Lambeth—we had two tame rabbits safe on the 7th of May—we missed them—this is one of them—I can swear to it—they were safe on Friday night, and gone on the Saturday.

RICHARD HOLWAY . I live in East-street, Lambeth. About five o'clock on Saturday afternoon, the 8th of May, the prisoner came to me, and asked if I would buy two rabbits—I said I could sell them for him—I took them to Ingram, and he bought them.
WILLIAM INGRAM . I bought these rabbits of Holway.

Prisoner's Defence. I bought them on the Saturday, between three and four o'clock; I gave 1s. 6d. for them; I asked Holway to buy them; he said he had left off keeping them, but he could sell them for me.

HENRY BUCKLEY (police-constable G 73.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction at this Court—(read—Convicted 30th March, 1846, having been before convicted of felony, confined one year)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Transported for seven Years.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, JUNE 14TH, 1847.
